analytic.title: An Extended Tennessee Eastman Simulation Dataset for Fault-Detection and Decision Support Systems

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This thesis contributes to the development of decision support systems for large industrial processes that depend on human supervisory control, such as production plants in the chemical, petrochemical and energy industries. Supervision of such systems requires the utilization of process knowledge for the contextualization of plant information and the formulation of viable operating strategies. These tasks demand constant attention from human operators on site and it has been shown that especially demanding situations can result in cognitive overload, which impairs the operators ability to make informed decisions, leading to human error. The contributions in this thesis present methods that contextualize process data and suggest operating strategies automatically or on-demand in order to focus the operators attention and improve human performance.

The chosen decision-support framework leverages information contained in causal process models, which encode the causal relations between process variables, operational states and production goals. Following a summary of the state of the art of causal process modeling, extensions related to causal propagation, diagnosis and planning are presented. Propagation algorithms are evaluated based on their utility for specific applications within diagnosis and planning. Ranking strategies for causal diagnosis, specifically root-cause analysis, are extended to incorporate more parameters to improve diagnostic accuracy. Regarding causal model-based planning, existing appraoches are extended by formalizing a semi-quantitative planning framework. The latter enables feedback dependent process re-configuration based on qualitative information about state transitions, which can be generated using causal propagation. The proposed methods for root-cause analysis and planning are evaluated using relevant case-studies.

The majority of the presented causal models are build using Multilevel Flow Modeling (MFM), a functional modeling language that facilitates the representation and analysis of complex industrial processes. Two of the presented contributions extend this modeling language; The first introduces the explicit inclusion of operator control actions in MFM and the second proposes the automatic extraction of causal models in the form signed directed graphs.

An open-source development and testing framework for causal analysis is detailed in two further contributions that feature a dataset and an improved simulator for the Tennessee Eastman process. The presented framework promises significant improvements for rapid testing and development of causal analysis techniques and generally facilitates research related to fault diagnosis and process re-configuration.
The thesis concludes with a discussion of the presented contributions, regarding academic and industrial relevance, utility and potential extensions.

I would like to thank my supervisors Professor Ole Ravn and Professor Emeritus Morten Lind for their support over the years. In terms of academic collaboration, I want to extend special thanks to Thomas Thuesen Enevoldsen, Denis Kirchhuebel, Associate Professor Roberto Galeazzi, Assistant Professor Xinxin Zhang, Jing Wu and Professor Murat Kulahci, whose support was essential for the publication of the papers presented in the this thesis.

Regarding feedback, general advice and encouragement I want to thank Dimitrios Papageorgiou, Thomas Thuesen Enevoldsen and the members of the MFM research team that have not been mentioned above, Emil Krabbe Nielsen, Asgeir Daniel Hallgrimmson and Mengchu Song. Generally, I would like to thank all colleagues at the group for Automation and Control (AUT) for providing a very welcoming and open work environment, entertaining and engaging discussions during lunch and coffee breaks, and their friendship.

The funding and opportunities provided by the Danish Hydrocarbon Research and Technology Center were gratefully received and the events hosted by the center gave interesting insights into the bigger picture of the conducted research. The close collaboration with Kairos Technology over the entirety of the PhD studies, but especially in the pre-pandemic times, was very valuable to the research effort and very much appreciated. The opportunities to collaborate directly with plant operators provided valuable industry feedback and and seeing theoretical developments made at AUT adopted and put into industrial practice added a great deal of motivation to the work.

Most importantly, I want to thank my family and my girlfriend for their unwavering support and encouragement. It is sometimes too easy to forget the many little things that made it possible to get to this point, but I will do my best to remember.

div.head: Resumé
div.p: Denne afhandling bidrager til udviklingen af beslutningsstøttesystemer til store industrielle processer, der afhaenger af menneskelig overvågning, som for eksempel produktionsanlaeg i den kemiske, petrokemiske og energi industri. Tilsyn med sådanne systemer kraever anvendelse af procesviden til kontekstualisering af processinformation og formulering af meningsfulde driftsstrategier. Disse opgaver kraever konstant opmaerksomhed fra menneskelige operatører, og det er påvist, at meget kraevende situationer kan resultere i kognitiv overbelastning, hvilket forringer operatørernes evne til at traeffe informerede beslutninger, som i sidste ende fører til menneskelige fejl. Bidragene i denne afhandling praesenterer metoder, der kontekstualiserer procesdata og foreslår driftsstrategier automatisk eller on-demand for at fokusere operatørernes opmaerksomhed og forbedre menneskelig ydeevne.

Det praesenterede beslutningsstøttesystem udnytter information indeholdt i kausale procesmodeller, som beskriver årsagsforholdet mellem procesvariabler, operationelle tilstande og produktionsmål. Den generelle tilgang til kausal procesmodellering er opsummeret, og udvidelser vedrørende kausal diagnose og planlaegning praesenteres. Kausale propagations-strategier evalueres ud fra deres anvendelighed til specifikke applikationer inden for diagnose og planlaegning, og gyldigheden af antagelser, der implicit foretages ved at vaelge visse propagations-metoder, diskuteres. Rankingstrategier til årsagsdiagnose, specifikt rodårsagsanalyse, udvides til at omfatte flere parametre, der svarer til menneskelige beslutningskriterier. Med hensyn til kausal modelbaseret planlaegning udvides eksisterende evalueringer ved at formalisere et semikvantitativ planlaegningssystem, der muliggør feedbackafhaengige proceskonfigurationer baseret på kvalitativ information om tilstandsovergange, som kan genereres ved hjaelp af kausal propagation.

Størstedelen af de praesenterede kausale modeller er bygget ved hjaelp af Multilevel Flow Modelling (MFM), et funktionelt modelleringssprog, der letter repraesentation og analyse af komplekse industrielle processer. To af de praesenterede bidrag udvider modelleringssproget; Den første introducerer den eksplicitte inkludering af operatørkontrolhandlinger i MFM, og den anden foreslår automatisk udvinding af kausale modeller i form af signed directed graphs.

Et open source-udviklings-og testsystem til årsagsanalyse praesenteres i yderligere to bidrag, der indeholder et datasaet og en forbedret simulator til Tennessee Eastmanprocessen. Udnyttelsen af det praesenterede system lover betydelige forbedringer til hurtig test og udvikling, og skaber muligheder for nye samarbejder, der ikke kunne opnås ved brug af proprietaere data.

De foreslåede metoder til rodårsagsanalyse og -planlaegning testes ved hjaelp af flere studier, og forbedringerne i forhold til den aktuelle teknik evalueres. Afhandlingen afsluttes med en diskussion af de praesenterede bidrag vedrørende akademisk og iv Resumé industriel relevans, nytte og potentielle udvidelser.

div.head: Preface
div.p: This thesis was prepared at the department of Electrical Engineering at the Technical University of Denmark (DTU) in partial fulfilment of the requirements for acquiring a PhD degree. The PhD project was financed by the Danish Hydrocarbon Research and Technology Center (DHRTC) in the CTR-1 "Operations and Maintenance Technology" programme.
The supervisors were:
• Professor Ole Ravn (main supervisor), Department of Electrical Engineering, Automation and Control, DTU
• Professor Emeritus Morten Lind (co-supervisor), Department of Electrical Engineering, Automation and Control, DTU

The thesis consists of a summary report of the findings of the PhD project and the collection of articles submitted to peer reviewed scientific journals and conference proceedings during the project period 2018-2021.

div.head: CHAPTER 1 Introduction
div.p: Operational safety and efficiency of large industrial processes is ensured through the combined application of automatic and human manual control. While automatic control systems handle the majority of low-level operations, human operators are tasked with plant supervision and re-configuration. If the automatic control system fails to meet the plant production or safety targets, it is the operators' job to determine the reason for the failure and decide on remedial actions. The presented contribution advances research for decision support systems for control room operators in large industrial processes with the goal of improving the operators decision making in emergency situations. The focus lies on the utilization of qualitative causal process models for on-line diagnosis and counteraction planning.

div.head: Background
div.p: The complexity of large-scale industrial plants in the chemical, petrochemical and energy industries has consistently increased over the past decades. The driving factors for the increase in complexity are performance improvements that can be gained from the implementation of sophisticated plant and control designs and improved plant monitoring strategies that feature higher degrees of instrumentation. While increasing sophistication of industrial plants generally has positive effects regarding performance, higher complexity inevitably increases the amount of risk factors that have to be considered, both in the design as well as the plant operating phase (Rothenberg, 2009). The pre-evaluation of risks during plant-design is one of the key factors that ensures safe operation and is thus the focus of many hazard and operability and safety management studies (Khan et al., 2015). Nonetheless, the continued occurrence of plant incidents (Mannan et al., 2016) reveals that risk mitigation strategies alone are insufficient to completely avert plant accidents.

While the occurrence of plant failures cannot be avoided through risk mitigation, the amount of failures that lead to severe accidents can be reduced through improved fault-detection and fault-management. Early detection of faults, using either modelbased approaches (Blanke et al., 2015) or data-driven techniques (Gomez-Fernandez et al., 2020;Park et al., 2020), has the potential to increase the amount of time that is available for fault-management. Going beyond fault-detection, the automatic isolation and identification of faults provide significant advantages. Data-driven faultisolation (Alauddin et al., 2018;Gomez-Fernandez et al., 2020) has progressed significantly in recent years, but the utility of the methods is contingent on the availability of large amounts of both nominal and faulty process data. Considering that most industrial plants in the chemical and energy industries feature unique designs and in-1 Introduction frequent, non-repetitive failure conditions (Bullemer et al., 2015), it can be expected that the application of data-driven techniques will be focused on fault detection rather than isolation in the coming years. Considering the current industry standard, it can be observed that while fault-detection is highly automated, the interpretation of detected alarms, comprising fault-isolation and -management, is addressed by human operators (Stauffer and Clarke, 2016). The operators leverage their process knowledge to contextualize the available information and make inferences about the plant condition. If the process condition is not satisfactory, suitable counteraction procedures are initiated to reach a desired state of operation.

For large and complex processes, such as most industrial production plants, faults are managed based on information that is provided in plant control rooms, which are designed to provide as much relevant information about the state of the process as possible, either through visual aids or audio cues in the form of trends and alarm signals. A plant diagram showing live sensor data is typically used to visualize the general plant state, while subsystem-operations are monitored in greater detail on separate screens. Over the years, the amount of displayed information has significantly increased, mostly due to the use of more instrumentation and remotely monitored systems. In addition to alarm signals and raw data, many modern systems feature self-diagnosis and automated re-configuration functionalities, which have to be taken into account. (Koffskey et al., 2013) The described increase in complexity and instrumentation results in larger quantities of unfiltered information that have to be processed by human operators on a continuous basis. In cases where the amount of presented information exceeds a certain limit at any given point, the operators ability to contextualize is reduced due to a necessity to focus on information retrieval. This can occur during nominal plant operation, for instance due to poorly configured alarm settings, but especially in emergency situations that affect multiple plant subsystems and thus lead to many alarms in a short amount of time. Many alarm management studies focus on the evaluation of the relevance and the subsequent elimination of unnecessary alarms in order to focus the operators attention on vital information (EEMUA, 2013). Emergency scenarios, however, tend to produce many true alarms that arise due to the high degree of component dependency in typical production environments. Specifically, that means that the malfunction of a single plant component will affect connected systems, so that multiple alarms are triggered even though only a single failure is present in the plant. The term cognitive overload describes the scenario in which the amount of unfiltered information exceeds what the human operators on site can process. If operators get overloaded, they tend to loose the ability to contextualize and relate the occurring events, resulting in decreased situational awareness and sub-optimal decision making. Countermeasures that are initiated in such situations often focus on treating the observed symptoms, rather than the true root-cause (Hollnagel, 2002), which can yield short-term results, but not a return to nominal operation. The analysis by Mannan et al. (2016) has shown that the outcome of many accidents summarized in their study could have been improved by execution of proper emergency procedures. The failure to execute correct procedures in high-pressure situations can be related to a lack of situational awareness, characterized by either incorrect perception or erroneous assessment of the plant state. Rather than attributing these issues to human operators, they can be traced back to a failure to incorporate assistive technology in the control room that provides sufficient help to human operators to enable them to maintain the required level of situational awareness. Even though the necessity of technology that directly assists human operators during the decision making process has been pointed out by Beebe et al. (2013), decision support systems are still not featured in most modern industrial control rooms.

Two features that can be provided by decision support systems are contextualization of unfiltered process measurements and automated suggestion of countermeasures in cases where such are required. For either application, interpretability of results in a human-understandable format will most likely be fundamental for process experts and control room operators, as pointed out by Venkatasubramanian (2019). Recognizing the need to exploit explainable AI for operator support in large-scale industrial plants, this contribution extends research into decision support systems that enable automated root-cause analysis and counteraction planning.

div.head: Research objectives
div.p: The main goals of the thesis are to extend the diagnostic capabilities of causal process models and to provide a suitable development and testing framework that facilitates the adoption of the new methods for industrial applications. Due to its extensive application in the field, Multilevel Flow modeling is chosen as the primary modeling language for the generation of causal process models. Considering the focus on MFM for modeling purposes, its relation to other representations of causal models must be clarified and extensions of the language that are required to enable its utilization for presented diagnostic and planning applications must be implemented. Considering this general guideline, specific objectives are to:
• Identify common features of MFM and other causal process models and enable model comparisons in a common framework.
• Extend the MFM modeling language so that all elements required to execute MFM based planning can be explicitly represented in MFM models.
• Contextualize the utility of causal propagation strategies for applications in diagnosis and planning
• Extend existing causal diagnosis methods to improve diagnostic accuracy.
• Create a generalized causal model-based planning framework that offers the potential to be extended with quantitative information.
• Create a test framework for causal models that facilitates the development and evaluation of new research ideas.
• Demonstrate the application of the proposed methods in illustrative case-studies of industrial relevance.

div.head: Structure of the thesis
div.p: The thesis presents the contributions to the development of a causal model-based operator support system that were made during the PhD study. The majority of the presented work directly relates to peer-reviewed research articles that were disseminated to journals and conferences. The thesis provides context for the submitted articles and their role in the development of an automated reasoning system. Following this introduction, Chapter 2 summarizes the submitted contributions.

The state of the art of alarm management and decision support systems that utilize causal analysis is summarized in Chapter 3. The state of the art further includes recent developments of Multilevel Flow modeling; the modeling method that is used as a reference for causal models throughout the thesis.
Direct extensions of Multilevel Flow modeling that were developed as part of the PhD project are presented in Chapter 4.

Developments related to causal analysis that are largely independent of the chosen modeling method are presented in Chapter 5. Guidelines on the use of existing as well as newly introduced causal analysis techniques for applications related to on-line diagnosis and action planning are proposed. The chapter further discusses ranking strategies for root-cause analysis and introduces the integration of causal-propagation into an on-line planning framework.

Chapter 6 focuses on practical issues related to the development and validation of causal models. The chapter introduces two contributions that facilitate access to data and simulation resources that are useful for the development of process diagnosis and re-configuration related research, including decision support systems. Drawbacks of existing databases and simulators are outlined and it is addressed how the presented contributions improve upon the mentioned issues.
Concluding remarks are given in Chapter 7 along with a discussion on future challenges related to the integration of the presented work in industrial applications.

The presented thesis contributes to the development of online operator support systems that are based on causal process models. The three main subjects of the project are general development of causal model-based reasoning, extensions of Multilevel Flow Modeling and the development of a simulation based test framework for process analysis.

Extending the general theory for causal process model based analysis and diagnosis, Appendix C presents a discussion of possible ranking strategies for root-cause analysis. Appendix E investigates the application of qualitative causal models for on-line process re-configuration to evaluate the suitability of the method for on-line counteraction planning in emergency situations on industrial plants. The contribution presented in Appendix G evaluates the suitability of causal analysis for processes with minimal instrumentation.

In order to extend the functionalities of Multilevel Flow modeling, Appendix F presents the explicit inclusion of operator control actions in MFM. Appendix D further promotes the comparison of MFM to generic causal process models by introducing a method for the automatic conversion from MFM models to signed directed graphs.

In order to utilize the well-known Tennessee Eastman process as a causal process modeling benchmark, Appendix A presents a new dataset for the process that contains relevant data for the development and testing of causal analysis approaches. Appendix B further extends the use of the Tennessee Eastman process as a benchmark by introducing a new simulator for the process that is tailored for the simulation of complex operating scenarios.

div.head: Journal Articles
div.p: (A) C. Reinartz, M. Kulahci, and O. Ravn (2021c). "An extended Tennessee Eastman simulation dataset for fault-detection and decision support systems." In:
Computers & Chemical Engineering. doi: https://doi.org/10.1016/j. compchemeng.2021.107281

The Tennessee Eastman Process (TEP) is a frequently used benchmark in chemical engineering research. An extended simulator, published in 2015, enables a more in-depth investigation of TEP, featuring additional, scalable process disturbances as well as an extended list of variables. Even though the simulator has been used multiple times since its release, the lack of a standardized reference dataset impedes direct comparisons of methods. In this contribution we present an extensive reference dataset, incorporating repeat simulations of healthy and faulty process data, additional measurements and multiple magnitudes for all process disturbances. All six production modes of TEP as well as mode transitions and operating points in a region around the modes are simulated. We further perform fault-detection based on principal component analysis combined with T2 and Q charts using average run length as a performance metric to provide an initial benchmark for statistical process monitoring schemes for the presented data.
(B) C. Reinartz and T. T. Enevoldsen (2021). "pyTEP: A Python package for interactive simulations of the Tennessee Eastman process." SoftwareX. Submitted April 2021

pyTEP is an open-source simulation API for the Tennessee Eastman process in Python. It facilitates the setup of complex simulation scenarios and provides the option of interactive simulation. The Tennessee Eastman process has been the go-to benchmark for statistical process monitoring and machine learning based fault-detection approaches for continuous chemical processes in recent years, but its potential outside these domains remains largely untapped. Existing simulators are tailored towards simulations of stationary operating conditions in the presence of faults, but further extensions for more complex simulation scenarios are time-consuming, which may discourage researchers from adopting the process. Through pyTEPs API, users can configure simulations, change operating conditions and store simulation data without being exposed to the underlying mechanics of the simulator. In addition to the newly introduced features, pyTEP promises more versatility and more straightforward usage than existing TEP simulators.

(C) C. Reinartz, X. Zhang, H. P.-J. Thunem, and R. McDonald (2021f). "Improving situational awareness through explainable AI -Automated root-cause ranking based on causal process models." Process Safety and Environmental Protection.

div.head: Submitted Mai 2021
div.p: Situational awareness of human operators on industrial plants is one of the key factors that ensures safe operation and correct responses to emergency situations. This contribution presents the application of functional causal process modeling for automated decision support systems that improve the operators situational awareness in abnormal operating scenarios by providing contextual information about the plant state and by isolating the most likely faults. A procedure to build models that accurately depict the causal dependencies in large-scale processes is described and applied in a case-study featuring a pressurized water reactor. Three operating scenarios that show process responses to abnormal operating conditions are simulated using a full-scale simulator and assessed by an experienced control-room operator. Novel reasoning and rootcause ranking algorithms for causal process models are presented and evaluated based on their root-cause detection performance for the presented scenarios. It is further detailed how the new algorithms are set-up to mimic a human oper-ators approach to root-cause analysis, including a discussion of the suitability of the employed approach as an assistive technology in modern control-rooms in the nuclear, chemical and petrochemical industries.

Conference Papers Intelligent fault diagnosis systems can be a major aid to human operators charged with the high-level control of industrial plants. Such systems aim for high diagnostic accuracy while retaining the ability to produce results that can be interpreted by human experts on site. Signed directed graphs have been shown to be a viable method for plant-wide diagnosis that can incorporate both quantitative information about the process condition as well as qualitative information about the system topology and the functions of its components. Their range of application in industrial settings has been limited due to difficulties regarding the interpretation of results and consistent graph generation. This contribution addresses these issues by proposing an automated generation of signed directed graphs of industrial processes in the chemical, petroleum and nuclear industries using Multilevel Flow Modeling; a functional modeling method designed for operator support. The approach is demonstrated through a case study conducted on the Tennessee Eastman Process, showing that Multilevel Flow Modeling can facilitate a consistent modeling process for signed directed graphs. Finally, the resulting benefits regarding qualitative reasoning for plant-wide diagnosis are discussed. This paper presents a planning framework for discrete planning of human operations in highly automated industrial plants, where manual and automatic control coexist. Based solely on qualitative knowledge of the controlled continuous process represented through signed directed graphs, the planner exploits a greedy algorithm to determine the optimal action for the human operator upon changes in the process' operating conditions or reconfiguration of the control system due to faulty conditions. The planner results in a decision support tool that instructs the human operator on the best course of action. The planning framework and the resulting planner are demonstrated on a quadruple-tank system.

(F) C. Reinartz, D. Kirchhubel, and X. Zhang (2021b). "Explicit representation of operator control-actions in Multilevel Flow Modeling." 26th IEEE International Conference on Emerging Technologies and Factory Automation. Submitted in June 2021

Multilevel flow models have been used for automated reasoning in control-rooms in complex industrial plants, mainly focusing on the representation of system design goals and online root-cause analysis. Further research into automated generation of counteraction plans in emergency scenarios has shown that a formal extension of the modeling language is required to extend it's utility for planning applications.

This contribution presents two novel modeling concepts for Multilevel Flow Models that are designed to enable the explicit representation of an operators means to interact with a system. The presented additions to the modeling language enable both the identification of viable actions as well as conditions for their execution. The applications of the new modeling concepts is demonstrated using a case-study featuring the primary system of a pressurized water reactor.

(G) C. Reinartz, J. Wu, A. Lindemann, and S. B. Jorgensen (2021e). "Automated operator support for small-scale production plants -A water treatment casestudy." 26th IEEE International Conference on Emerging Technologies and Factory Automation. Submitted in June 2021

This contribution presents the initial results of the application of an automated reasoning system for operator support using a case-study from the water industry. The case-study investigates an anomaly during the operation of a local water treatment plant in the greater Copenhagen area in Denmark, where unusually high amounts of ammonia and nitrite were sampled in the treated water.

A functional model of the system is created in order to enable the automated analysis of the anomaly, including proposals of the most-likely root-causes and counteraction measures. The generated reasoning results are evaluated by process experts and it is discussed how the developed model can aid human operators during the occurrence of similar anomalies and regarding the improvement of the implemented instrumentation scheme in the future. The differences regarding the application of functional modeling for smaller production plants compared to large-scale processes are discussed during the evaluation of the results. Planned extensions to implement the presented model as a full-time monitoring addition to the local waterworks and its distribution network are outlined.
CHAPTER 3

div.head: State of the art
div.p: As described in Chapter 1, this contribution focuses on decision support systems for control room operators. The state of the art summarizes industry standards and research developments related to human supervisory control, starting with current approaches to alarm management and concluding with intelligent decision support systems with a focus on causal process analysis.

div.head: Alarm management
div.p: While the term alarm management defines a broad range of topics, many of its aspects are related to the scrutiny of existing alarms (Rothenberg, 2009). This section focuses on alarm management related the evaluation and proper configuration of alarms, which is meant to ensure that triggered alarms provide meaningful input to operators in the control room. If alarms are triggered due to incorrect configurations, they indicate a non-existing problem and unnecessarily distract the operators. This issue is compounded if it occurs frequently or affects more than one alarm. The problem of such nuisance alarms is investigated by Hu et al. (2017b), who introduce an alarm analysis framework that identifies frequently occurring alarms that do not present immediate implications for operators. Following the identification of nuisance alarms, Hu et al. (2017a) present an approach that reduces frequently occurring, chattering alarms through improved configuration of alarm thresholds and delays. Another issue that needs to be addressed is the occurrence of multiple alarms that tend to occur in fixed groups or sequences. Such cases indicate redundant alarm configurations that could be improved by grouping the alarms and attributing them to specific process events, rather than presenting multiple, seemingly unconnected alarms to the operator. Groups of alarms that occur together can be identified using statistical alarm analysis, as shown by Charbonnier et al. (2014) and Soares et al. (2016). The provided examples provide a short overview of the general issue that poorly configured alarm systems can distract the operators attention, even in situations where the plant is operating nominally. Proper alarm system design is extensively researched and goes far beyond what has been presented in this section, but many of its applications address one of the two general issues presented above. Rothenberg (2009) provides a comprehensive best-practice guide for alarm design, which serves as a good addition to the guidelines and industry standards presented by EEMUA (2013), IEC (2014), andISA (2009).

div.head: Alarm floods
div.p: Although the correct configuration of alarm systems can reduce nuisance alarms and redundant alarm sequences, Beebe et al. (2013) points out that plant emergencies will still lead to sequences of true alarms in sufficient quantity to cause cognitive overload of control room operators. The estimated alarm quantity at which an operators ability to assess the plant state is impaired is set at 10 alarms within a 10 minute interval, which is referred to as an alarm flood (EEMUA, 2013). Assuming the successful application of alarm suppression and alarm grouping methods, the challenge is to correctly interpret the remaining sequence of true alarms, which is currently the done by human operators and which should be supported by intelligent decision support systems Stauffer and Clarke (2016).

div.head: Decision support systems
div.p: The boundary between alarm management and decision support systems is vague.

In this contribution, methods with the main focus to interpret and contextualize unfiltered plant data in order to present filtered, comprehensive information to plant operators are summarized under the term decision support system. Typical examples of filtered information that is of direct use to control room operators are suggestions about potential root-causes of observed process deviations and mitigation procedures that enable a return to nominal operation. An AI-guided reasoning system that utilizes answer set programming to encode domain knowledge is presented by Hanna et al. (2021) for a nuclear power-plant casestudy. Song et al. (2020) proposes an approach for the automated identification of counteraction procedures in a nuclear power plant that is based on functional process models. Kumari et al. (2020) address the issue of data scarcity for the identification of rare events in the chemical industry and present root-cause analysis for key process variables. Hu et al. (2015) connect plant failure symptoms and counteraction procedures by leveraging existing operating knowledge contained in HAZOP studies. Considering the scenario of sequences of true alarms described in Section 3.1.1, rootcause analysis methods aim to attribute the observed alarm sequences to a smaller set of process faults that are likely to lead to the observed sequences. Rodrigo et al. (2016) utilizes connectivity analysis combined with alarm logs to determine causal relationships between alarms in alarm floods. Other approaches to root-cause analysis are based on the identification of temporal alarm dependencies (Folmer et al., 2014), fault-trees (Dubois et al., 2010) and Bayesian networks (Wang et al., 2014).

Most of the presented decision support systems rely on offline knowledge acquisition, either from engineering documentation or process data. If the knowledge acquisition phase results in a model that encodes correlations or causal dependencies between process variables, e.g. in the form of fault-trees or Bayesian networks, the resulting model can be characterized as a causal process model.

div.head: Causal process models
div.p: Causal process models encode causal relations between process variables. The specific causal dependencies can be inferred from engineering documentation and from process data. The automated generation of causal process models from piping and instrumentation diagrams is investigated by Arroyo (2017) for general causal graphs and by Song and Lind (2020) for functional process models. Suresh et al. (2019) uses transfer entropy as a measure of causality for the semi-automated generation of hierarchical causal models, which are represented as signed directed graphs. Chen et al. (2018) use Granger-causality as a means to determine causality between process variables and define a systematic procedure for root-cause diagnosis for chemical process faults.

The majority of causal-model based analysis for the investigation of industrial processes is related to either fault diagnosis or action planning. Some contributions that utilize causal models have already been named in Section 3.2, e.g. those by Song et al. (2020) and Dubois et al. (2010). Hu et al. (2016) present the utilization of causal-graphs for the generation of a fault transferring probability matrix in order to perform fault diagnosis. Peng et al. (2014) incorporates information about historic malfunction frequencies into causal-graphs for a semi-quantitative diagnosis approach that leverages graph connectivity information in combination with failure frequencies by using Bayesian inference. Addressing the same data scarcity issue as Kumari et al. (2020), Wan et al. (2013) present root-cause analysis leveraging causal analysis specifically for the identification of faults for which no historic data is available. Further approaches that extend causal analysis towards semi-quantitative diagnosis are presented by Maurya et al. (2007) and Yang et al. (2012).

The majority of the presented causal modeling approaches utilize graphs as a tool for model representation, because they provide an explicit and clearly defined model definition. Signed directed graphs provide a concise representation of signed, directed causality and can easily be formalized (Bondy and Murty, 1976). Due to their generic nature, they are not constrained to the application in specific target industries and can be used as a benchmark representation for the comparison of different kinds of causal process models, which has led to their frequent adoption as a representational tool (Ma and Li, 2017;Suresh et al., 2019;Venkatasubramanian et al., 2003a).

div.head: Functional modeling
div.p: Functional modeling, a term primarily used in systems engineering and computer science, is a methodology for the structured representation of functions within a modeled systems or sub-system. A function can be either a specific process, action or task that a system is able to perform. Functional modeling languages often introduce a set of language and/or application specific symbols that describe specific sub-functionalities. Typical features of functional models include the representation of causal and temporal relations between process functions and operational principles, including conditions that have to be met in order to achieve function objectives. (Erden et al., 2008)

div.head: Multilevel Flow Modeling
div.p: Multilevel Flow Modeling (MFM) is a functional modeling language that aims to capture causal-dependencies on multiple levels of abstraction. As presented by Lind (2011a), the hierarchical dependency between high-level process goals and low-level process objectives is expressed through means-end relations, while the topological division of the system under investigation is expressed by flow-functions along the whole-parts dimension of the model.

div.head: Recent development of MFM
div.p: Recent MFM developments include all contributions published in 2011 and later, starting with the introduction to MFM provided by Lind (2011a). Most recent MFM related contributions name Lind (2011a) as the point of reference on which extensions of the modeling language are based. Zhang et al. (2013) presents an updated set of consequence reasoning rules for MFM and further presents the most recent summary of both cause and consequence patterns for MFM in Zhang (2015). Zhang and Lind (2017) introduces the formal inclusion of control-structure related language elements to MFM and Wu et al. (2020a) further introduces the concept of roles to the modeling language. Kirchhübel (2020a) presents multiple advances of MFM, mostly connected to extension of propagation and reasoning for fault-analysis. Most notably, Kirchhübel (2020a) introduces a reasoning algorithm that merges redundant reasoning paths, thus avoiding duplicate propagation and yielding performance improvements. Further, Kirchhübel (2020a) opens the discussion about potential rankings for MFM based root-cause analysis, such as distance-based ranking and probability-based rankings incorporating a Bayesian network approach. In order to incorporate dynamic features of a target system into MFM analysis, Kim and Seong (2018) propose the inclusion of time-to-detect and time-to-effect information.

Recognizing the need to clarify proper procedures for the MFM knowledge acquisition phase, Lind (2017) and Wu et al. (2020b) present modeling guidelines for MFM. To reduce the modeling effort, Song and Lind (2020) presents a concept for automated model generation using engineering documentation, specifically P&IDs.
In order to ensure the correct representation of causality in MFM models, Nielsen et al. (2018a) proposes validation procedures for MFM, which are extended by Nielsen et al. (2020).

Taking up the work by Gofuku and Tanaka (1997), Inoue et al. (2015) propose a scheme for the prioritization of plausible operation procedures in emergency plant scenarios that considers a procedures' ability to achieve the objective, its time to take effect and its general influence on the system. Song and Gofuku (2018) apply counteraction planning with MFM using a case-study of a station-wide blackout at a boiling water reactor and Song et al. (2020) further extend this work, presenting a model-based and rule-based synthesis for planning of severe accident management strategies. Wu et al. (2014) discusses the utility of MFM for computer-assisted HAZOP studies, highlighting how MFMs automated reasoning capabilities can aid during the hazard identification and evaluation process. The application of MFM for HAZOP is further discussed by Wu and Lind (2018) and Myllerup et al. (2019b). Myllerup et al. (2019b) highlights the potential re-usability of process knowledge captured in MFM models gathered from HAZOP studies for real-time operator decision support, thereby linking two major domains in which MFM is applied. Kirchhübel et al. (2019) summarizes the developments of MFM over the years and provides a graphical representation of the key contributions that led to extensions of the modeling language or present relevant case-studies. The timeline presented by Kirchhübel et al. (2019) is shown in Fig. 3.1. Figure 3.1: Chronology of MFM implementations, extensions and its application for operator support (Kirchhübel et al., 2019).
CHAPTER 4

div.head: Extensions of Multilevel Flow Modeling
div.p: This section focuses on the contributions directly related to MFM, starting with a summary of the current status in order to provide the necessary context for readers unfamiliar with the methodology. Following, the explicit inclusion of operator control actions, a topic vital for the formal inclusion and development of counteraction planning using MFM, is presented. Last, the automatic generation of signed directed graphs from Multilevel Flow models and its potential utility is discussed.

div.head: Current status of MFM
div.p: The majority of MFM research can be attributed to one of four domains:

• Model building -Modeling elements, guidelines and model validation The modeling guidelines (Lind, 2017) and approaches for automatic model generation from existing engineering documents (Song and Lind, 2020) mentioned in Section 3.4.1 promise improvements regarding the quality and consistency of MFM models, which is especially relevant for models of larger processes. Even better consistency would be achieved through the development of a generic modeling library containing premade component and sub-system models for frequently occurring systems as proposed by Lind, 2017. The relevance of proper modeling procedures and consistent model design cannot be understated, as any application of state-propagation and reasoning systems depends on the validity of the utilized model. This further highlights the importance of proper verification and validation procedures as presented by Nielsen et al. (2020). It is thus vital to validate the current manual and automatic modeling procedures (Lind, 2017;Song and Lind, 2020) through their application and validation for multiple large case-studies.

In contrast to the modeling procedure and structure of developed MFM models, which have seen considerable fluctuation over the years, MFM reasoning patterns have remained relatively consistent throughout MFMs development. Novelties to the reasoning patterns have typically extended the reasoning base, rather than breaking existing principles and rules. One open issue regarding state propagation with MFM is the proper handling of reasoning conflicts, which is implicitly addressed by most contributions that address MFM based reasoning, e.g. by Kirchhübel, 2020a for diagnostic applications and by Song et al., 2020 for counteraction planning, but which has to be addressed explicitly in order to clarify the implicit assumptions that are made by choosing specific conflict resolution strategies. It should be said that there is no ideal way to approach conflict resolution for qualitative reasoning approaches, such as MFM, but that the specifics of conflict resolution have to be adapted to the desired application. It is for example likely that MFM based root-cause analysis and MFM based counteraction planning require the application of different conflict-resolution strategies in order to produce meaningful results. The proper and explicit definition of such conflict resolution strategies remains one of the most relevant issues of MFM so far.

Root-cause reasoning and counteraction planning both rely on the proper definition of reasoning patterns and conflict-resolution approaches. The case-studies in the publications mentioned in Section 3.4.1.1 show promising results for MFM based analysis, but they typically feature the integration of additional information, such as pre-determined root-cause candidates or counteraction points that enable the presented analyses. An important step towards further improvement of MFM will be to explicitly include such information in the MFM model, so that similar analyses can be performed automatically by the reasoning system without requiring additional input. Another relevant issue is the definition of ranking procedures for root-causes and counteractions. The methods presented by Kirchhübel (2020a) and Inoue et al. (2015) supply a promising point to start the development of further ranking functions, but it is apparent that more development is required in this area, as neither author presents conclusive methods for ranking of MFM results.

div.head: MFM fundamentals
div.p: This section describes the fundamentals required to understand the MFM model structure and reasoning. It is meant to explain how MFM works, but does not elaborate on why the model syntax and reasoning system are designed as they are. For background information regarding why MFM is structured the way it is, the reader is referred to the contributions mentioned in Section 4.1.

The MFM function and relation primitives shown in Fig. 4.1 constitute the main building blocks of any MFM model, regardless of the domain of application. The division of systems and design intentions into causally dependent mass, energy and control flow structures makes MFM especially suitable for the description of continuous systems, such as production plants in the chemical and energy industries. Elementary flow functions are always enclosed in either mass, energy or control flow structures. Causal relations, meaning either influencer or participant relations, connect elementary flow functions belonging to the same flow structure. Means-end relations of the type mediate, producer-product and inverse producer-product connect elementary flow functions across different flow structures, but should not be used to connect functions inside the same flow structure. Means-end relations of the function- objective type (produce, maintain, suppress, destroy) connect from elementary flow functions to objectives and threats and are typically related to express process and control objectives. Condition relations (enable and disable) connect from objectives to elementary flow functions, expressing the concept that objectives or sub-objectives have to be satisfied for the enablement of specific flow functions. Specifically, current MFM logic supports enable relations from objectives to transport functions and disable relations from threats to barrier functions. Actuate relations are used specifically to express causal dependencies relating to control flow structures. The state of a system is expressed through qualitative states that are assigned to the elementary flow functions, objectives and threats in the MFM model. The qualitative states that MFM functions can assume are listed in Table 4.1. The presented MFM syntax encodes clearly defined, directed causal dependencies between flow functions and objectives. The causal dependency that is encoded is dependent on the involved flow functions and relations, the specifics of which are summarized in a rule-base that contains the instruction for all reasoning patterns, meaning all basic encodings of directed causality between MFM functions. Zhang (2015) provides the most recent and most complete summary of the utilized rule-base. An extract of the consequence reasoning rules as defined by Zhang (2015) is presented in Fig. 4.2 and Fig. 4.3 in order to convey the reasoning basics that are most relevant for this contribution. MFM reasoning is based on the propagation of proposed states from a source function to a target function. A normal state in the source function leads to a normal state in the target function, irrespective of the involved MFM flow functions and relations. High-high, High, Low and Low-low states propagate according to specific reasoning rules that depend on the involved flow-functions and relations. It should be noted that these basic propagation rules that make up the list of reasoning patterns do not consider how to address reasoning conflicts that can occur when a function to which a state should be propagated already has a state associated with it. This issue will be addressed in detail in the upcoming sections. (Zhang, 2015). Propagation source and target highlighted in red and white, respectively. (Zhang, 2015). Propagation source and target highlighted in red and white, respectively.

div.head: Explicit inclusion of operator actions
div.p: Regardless of the specific implementation of counteraction planning algorithms for causal models, a common denominator of such algorithms is the necessity to formally define an action space. Generally, that means that action plans can only be developed and evaluated, if the actions that can be performed are known beforehand. Current research efforts using MFM for counteraction planning define the sets of potential actions as additional information that is subsequently used to trigger MFM reasoning. Such an approach presents the drawback that knowledge about potential operator actions which might be present during the planning process, has to be stored separately, because MFM currently offers no means of encoding the information in the model. This section discusses the formal inclusion of operator control actions in MFM, which is a necessity if model-based planning is to be automated.

div.head: Operator control actions
div.p: Let the term operator control action be defined as a collective term for actions that are executable by a human control-room operator. Focusing the application to on-line operator support and plant re-configuration, the term is further narrowed down to consider short-term, directly executable actions, thus excluding repair and component changes. Operator control actions can be used for both plant re-configuration as well as counteraction planning, where counteraction planning implies a scenario in which the plant runs outside its nominal operating region and in which the automatic control system is unable to recover the plant state.

div.head: Actions in MFM
div.p: Previous studies investigating counteraction planning with MFM consider different approaches (Inoue et al., 2015;Song and Gofuku, 2018;Song et al., 2020), but all of them base their analysis on MFM propagation analysis starting at specific MFM functions. The functions at which the analysis is triggered correspond to operator control actions and are identified manually in the presented case-studies. The actions can further be subject to specific operating conditions that are required for their execution. The presented additions to the MFM modeling language allow the inclusion of information about operator actions inside the MFM model, so that future applications of counteraction planning can leverage the model without requiring additional information.

Two additions to the modeling language are introduced to encode the operators influence on a process through automatic and manual control systems. Additionally, the new modeling elements allow the encoding of conditional plant states that have to be satisfied in order for specific actions to be executable. Automatic control systems refer to closed-loop control that is part of the plant architecture and which can be manipulated by human operators through the adjustment of control set-points. Manual control refers to systems whose state can be adjusted directly by human operators, such as manual safety or block valves.

div.head: Manual control and out-of-scope automatic control
div.p: The MFM patterns displayed in Fig. 4.4 are used to describe control actions that are unrelated to automatic control loopsfoot_2 . The pattern introduced in Fig. 4.4 (a) shows a connection between a MFM flow function and an objective via a maintain relation. This pattern indicates the general ability of the operator to influence the connected MFM flow function state in either increasing or decreasing direction. The patterns in Fig. 4.4 (b,c) show connections between MFM flow functions and threats via suppress relations. These patterns indicate an operators ability to change the MFM state of the connected flow-function in the direction that opposes the hazardous state. The pattern featuring the low-threat Fig. 4.4 (b) e.g. indicates that the connected flow function can be increased by manual operator action. An example of a one-directional operator control action is given by a safety relief valve, which can be opened to release over-pressure, but which has no utility in cases of low system pressure. The low-threat and high-threat elements shown in Fig. 4.4 (b) and Fig. 4.4 (c) are new additions to the MFM modeling language.

div.head: Influence on automatic control
div.p: Automatic control actions are described by a singular MFM pattern, which is displayed in Fig. 4.5. This pattern remains unchanged from its original definition by Lind (2011b), so that backwards compatibility towards existing MFM models is ensured. The actuate relation (highlighted in Fig. 4.5) indicates that the manipulated variables (m) can be influenced by an operator through the manipulation of the control objective, which is connected to the controlled variable (c). A qualitatively similar behaviour is assumed regardless of whether the operator chooses to manipulate the control structure through an adjustment of the control objective (typically a set-point change) or through manual setting of the manipulated variable.

div.head: Modeling example
div.p: Fig. 4.6 highlights relations that correspond to the newly introduced features. The highlighted relations can be used to automatically extract information about which of the functions in the model can be changed by human operator actions. The model is an adaption of the model that is presented in the contribution presented in Section C, featuring additional information about the operability of the relief tank block valve (RC115) as a means of manual control. Aside from the mentioned addition, the model remains unchanged, showing that the implemented operator action logic is largely backwards compatible with existing models, as it mainly adds new logic to existing modeling patterns.

div.head: Extraction of signed directed graphs from MFM models
div.p: The summary of the current state of MFM in Section 4.1 lists model building, state propagation, root-cause analysis and counteraction planning as the main research tracks related to the methodology. Out of these four research tracks, only model building is related to knowledge acquisition and representation, while the other three tracks rely on the presence of an accurate static knowledge base in form of an MFM model for causal analysis. Considering that many applications of MFM for statepropagation, root-cause analysis and counteraction planning are mostly utilizing the causal dependencies encoded in MFM models, the question whether those causal dependencies can be converted to a generalized, more widely used framework for causality-representation, such as signed directed graphs, has to be posed and is investigated in the contribution in Appendix D. While such a conversion would potentially coincide with a loss of MFM-related benefits regarding presentation of information in a human-readable format, as well as the loss of additional information about types of causal relations (influencer, means-end, etc.), the utility of the resulting model for causal analysis could be maintained. Conversely, enabling the conversion of MFM models to signed directed graphs can benefit both research into causal analysis as well as MFM research. On the one hand, research focusing on graph-based fault analysis profits from the potential to utilize the existing functional modeling guidelines for model generation. On the other hand, research into MFM based causal analysis benefits, because the conversion of MFM models to signed directed graphs opens up possibilities to apply methods developed for graph-based fault diagnosis to MFM models.

div.head: Conversion procedure
div.p: The goal of the conversion is to use a MFM model as input and generate a signed directed graph that encodes identical causal relations between process variables as output. The procedure consists of three steps. In the first step, n graph nodes are created, n being the number of flow-functions and objectives in the MFM model. Subsequently, the causal relation between all connected pairs of nodes in the graph are determined in the second step. The explicit causality is determined for each pair of nodes that represents two directly connected MFM functions in the original model. The analysis of the MFM pattern in the original model and subsequent conversion to equivalent graph causality relations leverages the propagation rules presented by Zhang (2015) to determine sign and direction of the causal relations. Examples of the conversion of pair-wise MFM patterns to a pair of SDG nodes is provided for MFM influencer and participant relations in Fig. 4.7. In the third step, the identified causal relations are included in the SDG representation of the causal model through the addition of edges between nodes for which direct causal relations have been identified.

div.head: Graph reduction
div.p: As mentioned in Section 4.3, the conversion of MFM models to SDG offers the potential to apply existing graph analysis methods to MFM based causal models. One of the benefits of using a SDG based representation is that the SDG framework does not impose any structural constraints regarding the modification of the model, as long as the represented causal relations remain consistent with the original model. This allows e.g. the removal of process variables that are not relevant for specific analysis applications. In MFM, such a model reduction is subject to further constraints and would be significantly more difficult to implement, as the existing MFM model syntax would have to be maintained throughout the model reduction process. A reduction of the causal process model as described above can be useful for many practical applications, such as on-line process analysis, where it is often sufficient to only consider measured and manipulated variables, as those comprise the in-and outputs of the reasoning system.

The algorithm presented in Fig. 4.9 achieves a reduction of the causal model while preserving both direct as well as indirect causal relations between the retained graph nodes. The reduction algorithm consists of two steps. First, nodes with indegree ð - or outdegree ð + equal to zero are removed, unless they are contained in the set of nodes I that should be kept after reduction. The seconds step consists of recursive node removal. Basic node removal removes the node and all connected edges from the graph. In order to preserve indirect causality, the node removal process is extended, so that predecessors and successors of the removed nodes are connected with new edges that represent the same causal relation that used to be captured by the path from the predecessor to the successor via the removed node. The sign of the newly generated edge is determined as the product of the signs of the edges from predecessor to the removed node and the edge from the removed node to the successor.

div.head: Handling multigraphs after reduction
div.p: The application of the presented reduction algorithm can lead to the generation of a multigraphfoot_3 structure, if the original graph contains parallel, merging paths. An example of a graph whose partial reduction results in a multigraph is shown in Fig. 4.10. Generally, the only way to preserve all of the information from the original graph in the reduced graph is to maintain parallel edges. In the special case that parallel edges contain identical edge attributes however, it seems beneficial to perform a merging operation. For signed directed graphs that contain the sign of the edge as the only edge attribute, this means that parallel edges between the same pair of nodes can be merged, if they have the same sign. Fig. 4.10 (a) shows such a case, where both resulting parallel edges could potentially be represented by a single edge without loss of information, given that no additional edge attributes are present. The example in Fig. 4.10 (b) on the other hand cannot be further reduced through merging, since one edge has a positive sign while the other has a negative sign.

Step 1: It should be mentioned that any algorithm that preserves causality while reducing the graph must inevitably result in a multigraph, given that the original model possesses conflicting causal paths. This further indicates that any reasoning algorithm designed for the original graph model is still applicable to the reduced graph, as long as the formal requirements of handling multigraphs are considered correctly.
div.formula: while v i ∈ V \ I; ð -(v i ) = 0 ∨ ð + (v i ) = 0 do V ← V \ v i end while Step 2: while v i ∈ V \ I do for e + ∈ E; e + = (v m v i ) do for e -∈ E; e -= (v i v n ) do if v n ̸ = v m then e * = (v m v n ) E ← E ∪ e * end if end for end for V ← V \ v i end while

div.head: Case-study
div.p: The contribution in Appendix D presents a case-study in order to investigate the two most relevant points regarding the presented conversion and reduction algorithms. The first point that needs to be checked is that the conversion and potentially the subsequent reduction do not change the causality represented in the model. This is checked by applying the conversion algorithm to a reference model. Subsequently, single node graph propagation is applied to all nodes in the generated graph to create the resulting propagation trees. Similarly, MFM propagation is applied to all functions in the original MFM model, from which the graph was generated. The conversion is valid, if both generated propagation trees from the MFM model and the graph are identical. The second point that needs to be checked is whether a causal graph generated from an MFM model is similar to causal graphs created through other means. Identity is not required in this case, as the generation of causal graphs is parameterized for most methods and can thus produce deviating results even if the same method is applied with different sets of parameters. It is however expected that the causality between process variables is generally described similarly, even if different approaches are used, since causality is a property of the system. The Tennessee Eastman process is used as a reference case, because causal process models have been generated for the process in previous studies Ma and Li, 2017;Suresh et al., 2019. A MFM model, representing the reactor of TEP, is build for the case-study and subsequently converted to a signed directed graph. The model is shown in Fig. 4.11 and the reduced converted SDG is shown in Fig. 4.12. The utilized reference study includes a causal model of TEP that only considers instrumented process variables. In order to compare the results, the MFM generated SDG is further reduced using the presented algorithm, so that only nodes that represent process variables remain in the graph. A subsequent comparison between the reference graph and the MFM generated and reduced causal graph show strong similarities, which is a good indicator that, at least for the case-study, MFM models result in similar representations of causality as other methods that are frequently used for causal model generation.

Figure 4.12: SDG describing the causality between instrumented process variables related to TE-Reactor. Black edges: Causalities generated from the MFM model. Red edges: Causalities described in the reference study by Ma and Li, 2017 that do not appear in the MFM-generated SDG.

div.head: Summary
div.p: As a modeling language under active development, it is natural that MFM is extended whenever new applications require the implementation of additional modeling features. In order to enable counteraction planning, the language is extended with new modeling patterns that enable the explicit representation of operator control actions, which was identified as a required modeling feature.

Considering the frequent use of MFM for causal analysis, the presented framework for automated extraction of causal graphs from MFM models facilitates future comparisons between MFM based analysis and other approaches presented in the literature.

Causal model-based analysis comprises all methods that leverage information contained in a causal process model. Many of the basic principles that are applied for causal model-based analysis, such as state propagation or structure analysis, are directly adopted from graph analysis, as most models that encode causal information can be represented as graphs, as shown for MFM models in Section 4.3. The challenge regarding the development of methods for causal models is to adapt existing graph algorithms to fit specific design criteria. It should further be mentioned that those criteria can differ, depending on the application that the causal model is used for. It is for instance very likely that diagnosis and planning applications will require substantially different analysis approaches that leverage information contained in causal models in different ways. The following sections present various options for causal propagation and reasoning for both fault analysis and planning. Some of the presented methods have been shown in previous publications, mentioned in Section 3, but no publication known to the author provides a comprehensive overview of the benefits and drawbacks of causal propagation and analysis approaches in the context of diagnosis and planning.

div.head: Model definition
div.p: The following sections represent causal models as signed directed graphs, for which many similar formal definitions exist. The definition provided below follows the description of SDGs by Bondy and Murty (1976), with minor modifications to naming conventions and the addition of edge weights. Although the focus is on the interpretation and evaluation of propagation and conflict resolution strategies, rather than formal definitions, a clear notation for causal models and propagation functions is required to describe the different strategies unambiguously.

A causal model is represented as a graph G = (V, E, s, sign, w), where specific nodes v in the set of all nodes V represent system variables and the edges E represent directed causal dependencies between nodes. Edges e ∈ E can be expressed as e = (v i , v j ), for an edge that originates in node v i and leads to node v j . The nodes v i and v j are referred to as parent and child nodes, respectively. A state s : V → [-1, 1] is assigned to each node for the generic case of semi-quantitative or quantitative analysis. For qualitative analysis, the state definition is often further constrained, so that s : V → {1, 0, -1}. The function sign : E → {1, -1} maps each edge to a sign 1 , indicating positive or negative causal relations. The function w : E → [0, 1] assigns a weight to each edge. If not otherwise specified, w(e) = 1 is assumed.
Propagation between two nodes is expressed through a function ϕ
div.formula: ϕ(v i , v j , sign((v i , v j )), w((v i , v j )), s(v i )) → [-1, 1],
div.p: which returns the state s(v j ) of the child node. For convenience, the syntax of the propagation function is shortened to ϕ(v i , v j ) → [-1, 1], whenever the graph on which the propagation is applied can be referenced to extract the omitted arguments. In addition to propagating in the direction of causalityfoot_6 (forward propagation), states can be propagated in the opposite direction (backward propagation). Backward propagation will be described by the function ϕ -1
div.formula: ϕ -1 (v i , v j , sign((v i , v j )), w((v i , w j )), s(v j )) → [-1, 1],
div.p: which returns a state for the parent node v i . Like the forward propagation function, the expression will be shortened to
div.formula: ϕ -1 (v i , v j ) → [-1, 1], if possible.
div.p: Backward propagation is the direct complement of forward propagation, so that ϕ(ϕ -1 (v i , v j )) = s(v j ), which means that propagating back and forth does not affect the state of the original propagation source.
div.formula: A function γ(s 1 (v j ), s 2 (v j ), ...) → [-1, 1
div.p: ] is defined to resolve reasoning conflicts in cases, where two or more different propagation paths lead to the same target node v j to avoid assignments of multiple states s(v j ).

div.head: Clarification of vital terminology
div.p: The definition above introduces the terms source, target, parent and child for pairs of nodes. In this thesis, the terms parent and child are used to refer to a structural property of a graph. If a graph contains an edge e = (v i , v j ), then v i is said to be the parent and v j is said to be the child.

The terms source and target are used to refer specifically to state propagation. If a state is propagated from v i to v j , then v i is said to be the source of the propagation and v j is said to be the target. That means that, for forward propagation, source and target are equivalent to parent and child, respectively. For backward propagation, the roles are reversed, which means that for ϕ(v i , v j ), v i is the source node, while for ϕ -1 (v i , v j ), v j is the source node. In both cases, v i is the parent, since the edge (v i , v j ) is defined to lead from v i to v j regardless of which propagation function is applied.

div.head: Propagation
div.p: State propagation forms the basis of most causal analysis. This contribution considers a generic recursive propagation approach originating in a single root node. The following description uses forward propagation as an example, but can be applied in a similar way to backward propagation. The root node is considered as the source node of the initial propagation and propagates to all connected child nodes, resulting in the assignments of inferred states to all nodes that are connected to an edge originating in the root. The following iteration propagates to all child nodes of those nodes that were assigned a state in the previous iteration. This procedure is repeated, until reasoning conflicts (multiple states are assigned to the same node) have to be resolved or until all nodes reachablefoot_7 from the root have been assigned a state. The order of recursive propagation can differ based on the concrete implementation of the propagation algorithm (e.g. breadth-first vs depth-first propagation) and has to be considered to ensure consistent results given the implemented conflict resolution strategy. The following section does not present specific propagation algorithms, but rather assumes that the implemented propagation algorithm operates such, that no reasoning conflicts are overlooked and that all information to resolve a reasoning conflict is gathered before the application of the reasoning resolving function γ(s 1 (v), s 2 (v)).

div.head: Propagation in qualitative models
div.p: For purely qualitative models, where the state of a node is further restricted to be s : V → {1, 0, -1}, the state propagation function takes the form:
div.formula: s(v j ) = ϕ(v i , v j , sign((v i , v j )), s(v i )) = s(v i ) • sign((v i , v j )).
div.p: Assuming trivial propagations starting with s(v root ) = 0 are not considered, all reasoning conflicts for qualitative propagation can be summarized as follows: Multiple paths from the propagation root lead to a node v i and they do not all result in the same state s(v i ), meaning that s(v i ) = 1 for some paths and s(v i ) = -1 for other paths. If all paths leading from the root to v i result in the same assignment s(v i ) = 1 or s(v i ) = -1, there is no reasoning conflict. Fig. 5.1 shows two causal models, which will be used as references to clarify the introduced propagation and conflict resolution concepts. Applying forward propagation to the reference graph R1 in Fig. 5.1 e.g. produces consistent results so that no conflict resolution is required, as shown in Fig. 5.2. If forward propagation is applied to reference graph R2 starting with s(A) = 1, a reasoning conflict has to be resolved in node E, because the path A-B-C-E results in s(E) = 1, while the path A-B-D-E results in s(E) = -1. Considering that the model contains no information about which of the two propagations should take precedent, there are two ways to handle the propagation of node E that do not bias the evaluation towards either propagation path; generation of a graph that contains all possible (including conflicting) propagation paths or retraction of the assigned states of node E and all subsequent nodes in the propagation.

div.head: Nondeterministic propagation
div.p: The term nondeterministic propagation is introduced here in order to express the idea that a qualitative causal model contains no information about the relative probability of contradicting propagation paths and that reasoning conflicts cannot be resolved as a consequence. Applied to the example shown in Fig. 5.3 (a), that means that the states of nodes E and F are either

but that there is no information regarding which of the two options is more likely. The only thing indicated by the model is that E and F must have the same state. Nondeterministic propagation has the useful characteristic that it retains the maximal amount of information that can be gathered from the propagation. Its drawback is that the nondeterministic propagation graph might contain a lot of information that is not useful for practical applications. For a planning application e.g., the information that the states of E and F could be both positive or negative might not be utilizable. Kirchhübel (2020a) presents such a propagation strategy for MFM reasoning.

div.head: Retracting conflicting paths
div.p: If it is known beforehand that propagations that follow unresolved reasoning conflicts hold no value for further analysis, a retraction strategy can be applied. Fig. 5.3 (b) shows the application of a retraction step to the propagation applied to reference model R2. Because node E would be assigned conflicting states, the retraction algorithm removes node E and all subsequent propagations from further consideration. The remaining propagation graph thus contains only nodes for which an unambiguous state can be inferred. The presented conflict resolution methods can be applied to backward reasoning in the same way, as illustrated by Fig. 5.4. In the presented backwards reasoning example, the source of the propagation algorithm is s(F) = 1 for reference model R2. Iterative application of ϕ -1 starting at s(F) = 1 produces consistent inferences for nodes C, D, E and F, but results in reasoning conflicts for nodes A and B. As for forward propagation, the conflict can be treated nondeterministically by propagating all paths or retracted by removing A and B from consideration.

div.head: Propagation with additional information
div.p: If the graph contains additional information in the form of edge attributes, the propagation can be extended. Fig. 5.5 shows a reference model R3 that contains quantitative edge weights w. If node states are defined as s : V → [-1, 1], the state propagation function can be extended to
div.formula: ϕ(v i , v j , sign((v i , v j )), w((v i , v j )), s(v i )) = s(v i ) • sign((v i , v j )) • w((v i , v j )). (5.2)
div.p: Even if s : V → {-1, 0, 1}, the states should be propagated as indicated in Eq. 5.2.

A generalization to qualitative states should be performed after the propagation is complete since immediate generalization to qualitative states could lead to misrepresentations regarding the relative ratios of propagated states. A simple conversion to qualitative states can be achieved by applying a function g(x) = sgn(x), where sgn is the signum function.
Figure 5.5: Reference model R3. Quantitative information in the form of edge weights is added, which allows the utilization of more conflict resolution strategies.

Using quantitative propagation, reasoning conflicts can be handled through the application of a quantitative function γ(s 1 (v), s 2 (v), ...), such as (5.3) which in turn ensures that the resulting state lies within the defined bounds [-1, 1]. A sensible definition of γ depends on the quantity that is represented by the chosen edge attribute. In a generic probability propagation example for instance, γ must produce results that lie within [0, 1], as other values would not represent valid probabilities. Generally, using quantitative propagation instead of qualitative propagation only benefits the analysis if the utilized quantitative edge attributes can provide reliable information about either the likelihood or the magnitude of the propagated values and should be avoided if neither of these criteria can be satisfied.
