The causal models that can be extracted from MFM models for example do not contain edge weights that are inherently reliable for applications for quantitative propagation, which means that MFM based quantitative propagation approaches such as proposed by Kirchhübel (2020a) should be applied with caution. Fig. 5.6 shows the results of weighted propagation with the application of Eq. 5.2.

div.head: Special propagations
div.p: The previous sections cover basic propagation and conflict resolution for general cases. However, certain graph patterns and representations of elements of the physical system with special properties benefit from the implementation of additional reasoning logic.

div.head: Loops
div.p: A frequently occurring special case is presented when the causal model contains loops, meaning paths in the graph that form a circular dependency. Loops can either be consistent (positive feedback loop) or inconsistent (negative feedback loops). Positive feedback loops in qualitative causal models can be handled easily, since they do not cause any reasoning conflicts. The only thing that has to be ensured is that the propagation algorithm does not propagate infinitely within the loop. Negative feedback loops inevitably generate reasoning conflicts. Further, loop conflicts cannot be addressed through the application of nondeterministic propagation, since the generated paths would contradict themselves, meaning that differing states would be assigned to nodes on a single path from root to leaf. Considering that nondeterministic propagation is not possible, retracting the conflicting node and propagating the original state of the loop initiation point remains a valid propagation option. It has to be mentioned however, that loop retraction in qualitative graphs also does not necessarily reflect the true behaviour systems with circular causal dependencies in physical systems, which is a known drawback of qualitative process models in general.

div.head: Control-loops
div.p: Control-loops are a special case of negative feedback loops. Considering that the intended behaviour of the control-system that is represented by a control-loop in a causal process model is known, special propagation rules can be implemented to reflect said behaviour. An example of how control-loops can be treated differently from normal negative feedback loops and potential benefits for causal reasoning are described in the contribution in Appendix E, where it is assumed that a functioning controller tasked with keeping a variable at steady state will achieve its function through the modification of the manipulated variable in opposite direction of the initial deviation. The resulting causal propagation thus assumes a 0 state for the controlled variable and all children, except for the manipulated variable, which is

div.head: Diagnosis
div.p: This section focuses on diagnosis using qualitative models. Some of the presented approaches can be extended to include additional quantitative information, as shown e.g. by Kirchhübel and Jørgensen (2019), who show how to combine information from qualitative functional models with Bayesian fault analysis. Even though extensions that utilize quantitative reasoning promise performance improvements, the majority of causal models that are currently used for diagnosis do not contain sufficiently complete quantitative information, so that analysis has to be, at least in part, qualitative. The application of qualitative analysis consequently requires the definition of qualitative states that describe the state of the system. A generic set of qualitative states can be defined by assuming that every node in the causal model can assume the states {-1, 0, 1}, as defined in Section 5.1. For physical systems with set operating regions, these states can be used to express that a variable is lower than expected, nominal, or higher than expected. A straight forward conversion to qualitative states can of course be achieved by leveraging existing alarm thresholds, but alternative approaches, such as the use of qualitative trend analysis (Maurya et al., 2006) have also been suggested. For research purposes, another option is to leverage the knowledge of process experts to determine at which point in the progression of abnormal events they would classify specific process deviations as relevant, as was done for the contribution in Appendix C. Such an approach is not practical for the on-line integration of diagnostic systems, however. It must further be stated that the discretization of quantitative process variables to qualitative states can result in more than three possible states. MFM for instance uses additional states high-high and low-low to further distinguish highly critical process deviations. Regardless of the number of qualitative states that are introduced, the conversion from quantitative data introduces potential uncertainty about the validity of the qualitative states.

Considering the use of alarm thresholds, it becomes apparent that the proper definition of qualitative states is dependent on well-defined alarm thresholds and that poorly defined alarm thresholds can potentially lead to bad input to the reasoning system through the incorrect assignments of qualitative states. While the potential for incorrect inputs to the reasoning system should be considered, it must first be investigated what performance can be obtained if correct input is provided, whereas the investigation of how to make causal analysis robust to imperfect inputs should be a subsequent consideration. Under this premise, the following propagation and ranking methods for diagnosis are presented with the general assumption that all inputs to the reasoning systems as valid.
In order to facilitate the following explanations, relevant terminology is introduced:
• Assumption: Assumption about a state of a model node s(v) that is unrelated to propagation or observations.foot_9
• Inference: Assumption about a state of a model node s(v) that results from the application of state propagation.
• Evidence: Assumption about a state of a model node s(v) that results from an observation (e.g. sensor reading or alarm signal).
• Root-cause analysis: Term used for specific kind of diagnosis that assumes that the majority of process deviations can be attributed to a single cause; the root-cause.

Most causal-model based diagnosis focuses on root-cause analysis, trying to identify which process fault could potentially result in the set of evidences that is observed for a given alarm situation. Two general strategies can be distinguished for root-cause analysis, depending on which initial assumptions are chosen to start causal propagation. For the first strategy, a set of potential root-cause candidates is identified during model development. Subsequently, forward propagation is applied to identify all inferences that can be reached by propagating from the initial assumption that one of the identified root-cause candidates is active. The second strategy applies backwards propagation, using evidences as the initial propagation source nodes. Approaches following this strategy do not necessarily require the a-priori definition of root-cause candidates, but it can still be beneficial. Kirchhübel (2020a) presents a strategy that applies backwards propagation together with a path merging approach that identifies likely fault-trees for a given set of evidences. One of the main benefits of the second strategy is that only parts of the model that are directly relevant to a given scenario are investigated, because the reasoning propagation always starts at the evidences, which are by definition relevant for the investigation of the scenario. The second analysis promises improvements regarding performance of the implemented algorithms, but requires more extensive rules for the maintenance of the correct fault trees. The methods presented in the coming subsections focus on the first strategy, as it allows a simpler generation of fault-trees and thus faciliates the evaluation of different propagation and diagnosis strategies, because no additional maintenance rules have to be considered.

div.head: Propagation for root-cause analysis
div.p: The general procedure for root-cause analysis, starting with the propagation from pre-defined root-cause candidates, can be summarized in three steps.
1. Choose root-cause candidate to evaluate.
2. Apply forward propagation starting at the root-cause candidate.
3. Compare the inferred states to the existing evidences.

Considering that the information about root-cause candidates in the presented approach is static information that is available prior to the application of on-line analysis, the first two steps of the procedure are typically part of pre-compilation to increase efficiency. A likely root-cause candidate will produce inferences that conform to most, or all, observed evidences. The main design choice for the cause analysis method is the choice of the propagation algorithm. Considering purely qualitative models, it has to be evaluated whether nondeterministic propagation or retracting of reasoning paths are more suitable for root-cause analysis. The main drawback of retracting reasoning conflicts for diagnosis is that information about valid inferences that can result from a chosen root-cause candidate could be ignored, if they are subject to reasoning conflicts at any point of the propagation. That means that it is possible that symptoms that should be attributed to a root-cause are ignored, even though the causal model encodes the correct causal relation between the root-cause and the symptom. Considering that this loss of information is undesirable, nondeterministic propagation must be taken under consideration. Nondeterministic propagation will not result in loss of information, but it has to be specified how conflicting reasoning paths are interpreted. The most straight forward interpretation for contradicting parallel paths is that both represent possible propagation scenarios that can develop. Which scenario takes effect can only be determined if additional evidences support one propagation path or the other. The nondeterministic approach is a good reflection of a human-operators reasoning process, as it reflects that multiple scenarios are possible and that certainty about the true scenario can only be obtained through further information. The drawback of the nondeterministic approach is that it often results in too many potential results. To address this fact, it is necessary to define further criteria that distinguish likely from possible root-causes through quantitative rankings based on a set of evidences and a nondeterministic propagation trees.

div.head: Ranking root-cause candidates
div.p: Functions must be defined to rank the identified root-cause candidates, given a set of evidences and a set of inferences. Since causal analysis is partially developed for operator support systems, one logical approach is to model the ranking function after a human operators understanding of what constitutes a likely root-cause for a given scenario. To this end, the contribution presented in Appendix C presents two possible ranking functions. The first function evaluates how many evidences can be explained using the inferences. This approach has the potential drawback that the analysis might be biased towards root-cause candidates with a large propagation graph (meaning that many nodes are causally connected to the root-node). In order to reduce this issue, a second propagation algorithm is presented, which considers three typical questions human operators ask themselves when analysing a scenariofoot_10 :
• How many, and which of the evidences that are observed can be explained by the investigated root cause?
• How many, and which of the evidences that are observed cannot be explained by the investigated root cause?
• How many, and which additional evidences would be expected to appear if the investigated root-cause was present, but are currently not observed?

In order to consider these questions in a ranking function, the following quantities have to be extracted from the inferences and evidences: The number of evidences that can be explained by propagation from the root-cause (n explained ), the number of evidences that constitute the scenario (n observed ) and the number of evidences that would be expected according to the propagation (n expected ). Considering these variable definitions, the ranking function that only counts explained evidences can simply be expressed as rank 1 = n explained . The second introduced ranking function rank 2 further considers the questions for root-cause analysis posed above by including n observed and n expected in its definition as shown in Eq. 5.4. This ranking penalizes root-causes with inferences that are expected but not supported by observations.
div.formula: rank 2 = n 2 explained n observed • n expected .
div.p: The application of both ranking functions for the exemplary models in Fig. 5.8 is shown in Fig. 5.9 and Fig. 5.10. For both cases it can be observed that the penalization of unexplained but expected evidences leads to more structured results. For ranking example E1, the second ranking method simply expresses, that s(D) = 1 is the most likely root-cause, because this assumption explains all evidences while it would not result in any other inferences, according to the causal model. The calculated rank for node B e.g. is lower, because the inferences s(B) = 1 and s(C) = 1 are expected, but not observed. Using rank 1 , nodes A, B, C and D are assigned equal rank, as s(A), s(B), s(C), s(D) = 1 can each explain both observed evidences. The second example E2 and the respective rankings show the same comparison on a slightly more complex example. s(I) = 1 is ranked most likely, as it explains all evidences while producing only few inferences that are not supported by observations (s(C) = 1 and s(I) = 1). The important thing to note regarding example E2 is the relatively low rank assigned to s(B) = 1. s(B) = 1 is able to explain six of the seven presented evidences, but the applied ranking function actually only considers the evidences associated to nodes F, G, D and E. The supported evidences for nodes L and M are not considered, because they are dependent on an inference for node K that contradicts the evidence for node K. Propagation in the causal model starting at
div.formula: s(B) = 1 results in the inference s(K) = 1, but an observation suggests s(K) = -1.
div.p: The implemented algorithm assumes that any inference following such a contradiction cannot be regarded as valid, which results in the low rank assigned to s(B) = 1. The It is assumed that all featured nodes can be considered as root-cause candidates for the ranking.

case-studies included in the contribution presented in Appendix C further indicate that the explicit consideration of the number of expected deviations n expected improve analysis, especially with regards to a clear distinction between the most likely rootcauses and less-likely candidates.

The majority of root-cause analysis methods presented in Section 3 only consider which observed deviations or alarms can be explained, thus resulting in similar ranking approaches as rank 1 . Considering the apparent improvements that can be reached by considering more decision variables, it is interesting to evaluate other possible ranking functions that could be defined based on the three presented criteria. The function rank 2 is defined in such a way, that it results in a ranking between 0 and 1, where 0 expresses that no evidence that constitutes the operating scenario can be explained by the evaluated root-cause, whereas 1 expresses that all observed evidences can be explained and that there are no further evidences that would be expected if the root-cause was present. This function is specifically designed to evaluate rootcauses under the single-fault hypothesis, which means that it is expected that only a single fault is present in the system and that all observed deviations can be attributed to it. If it is assumed that multiple faults can be present, other ranking functions might become more relevant. For instance, a ranking function that considers how many of the expected deviations of a root-cause are actually observed in a given scenario, so that rank 3 = n expected and observed /n expected could be useful to identify faults whose fault-signature provides a very good fit for subsets of the evidences. Thorough evaluation and comparison of the different ranking strategies requires further and more extensive test-cases, however, which is addressed in Chapter 6. It must further be evaluated at which level of process complexity and for which amount of instrumentation the presented qualitative analysis methods provide most value. For small processes with little instrumentation for instance, the diagnostic accuracy that can be obtained from qualitative analysis is limited, as is discussed in the contribution in Appendix G. Considering that current literature does not yet provide a comparison of diagnostic accuracy for causal analysis depending on the model size and complexity, it can only be generally stated that the presented analysis approach is expected to yield increasingly useful returns with increasing degrees of instrumentation, but that further case-studies are required to confirm this assumption.

div.head: Planning
div.p: This section focuses on planning using qualitative causal models. The same definitions for the terms assumption, inference and evidence as in Section 5.3 are used. Similar to the definition of root-cause candidates in the previous section, action-candidates are defined in this section. Action-candidates describe nodes in the causal model that represent directly manipulable variables in the system. The identification of such variables is typically part of the modeling process and the information can either be stored separately or encoded into the causal model, as is shown in Section 4.2 for MFM. Song et al. (2020) and Song and Gofuku (2018) present causal model based planning applied to MFM. The presented approaches follow the general premise that certain nodes in the process model represent enabling functions that need to be activated in order to initiate counteraction procedures in abnormal plant situations. Counteractions for abnormal plant management are subsequently identified as those actions for which forward propagation indicates the potential to mitigate observed deviations. Side-effects of the proposed actions are not considered. Plans using the described approach can be developed in open-loop and represent qualitative action strategies that operators can follow to re-configure a process. Benefits of the mentioned methods include that existing procedures can be encoded in a causal model, which presents interesting applications especially in highly regulated industries with strict requirements regarding plant operation, such as the nuclear industry. One potential drawback is that the presented approach might result in a modeling practice that promotes the direct representation of specific operating scenarios rather than general plant functionality. Further, the extendibility of purely qualitative planning approaches for cases where quantitative information is available is limited. Even though there are a few open issues, Song and Gofuku (2018) and Song et al. (2020) show very promising results for realistic, large-scale process analysis and action planning using the qualitative, propagation based planning approach.

Rather than using a qualitative planning approach, Appendix E investigates whether the results of a qualitative propagation based analysis using causal models can be integrated into a quantitative planning framework. This promises the potential extension of developed methods with quantitative process knowledge to increase performance and enables the utilization of known theory for quantitative planning. The general idea is to consider process re-configuration as a generic path planning problem, where the problem formulation demands to change the operating condition from a starting configuration to a desired goal configuration. The main elements of the planning framework are presented in Section 5.4.3 and the remaining definitions are described in the contribution in Appendix E.

div.head: Propagation for planning applications
div.p: Section 5.3.1 discusses the merits of nondeterministic and retracted propagation for diagnosis and determines that the loss of information resulting from retracted propagation is undesired for many diagnosis applications, while nondeterministic propagation is suitable for the integration into diagnosis applications. For planning applications, the loss of information when using retracted propagation presents a similar issue as for diagnosis. Nondeterministic propagation, however, introduces too much uncertainty about the potential effects of actions, which reduces its feasibility for applications that consider planning that goes beyond the identification of suitable action-candidates. Different from diagnosis, where the specific nondeterministic propagation path can be determined from a set of evidences, planning usually requires the evaluation of an action before its consequences can be fully validated through feedback. In this context, the information that an action can lead to either an increase or a decrease of a specific state in the causal model is simply not particularly useful. Considering these issues regarding nondeterministic propagation, reasoning conflicts must either be retracted with the knowledge that certain consequence paths will not be included in the propagation analysis or a deterministic conflict resolution strategy that leverages additional information, such as presented in Section 5.2.3 must be applied. Appendix E considers a conflict resolution strategy based on path-length and special propagations for control loops, as presented in Section 5.2.3.2. It has to be stated that path-length is typically not suitable for conflict resolution, since it does not necessarily relate to either probability or magnitude of propagation. However, for the example in the mentioned contribution the applied conflict resolution strategy results in a correct representation of qualitative effects. The method that is used for state propagation, including the conflict resolution strategy, is listed in Algorithm 1. The algorithm maintains a list of active nodes A and dead nodes D in order to track and resolve potentially occurring reasoning conflicts and applies special propagation rules in cases that involve so-called control edges, which indicate that the encoded causal relation represents information transfer inside a control-loop. In the case-study in Section 5.4.4, the application of the state propagation algorithm to a causal model is shown. The state propagation results in the effect matrix shown in Eq. 5.5.

div.head: Effect matrix
div.p: Instead of utilizing state propagation for planning directly, the approach presented in Appendix E uses it for the generation of a qualitative state transition function, which can subsequently be integrated into a planning framework. The qualitative state transition function is called effect matrix. The matrix in Eq. 5.5 is used as an

div.head: Algorithm 1 Effect propagation algorithm
div.formula: Given: G = (V, E), vstart ∈ V , s (vstart) ∈ {-1, 0, 1, {}} A ← [vstart], D ← {vstart} while A ̸ = {} do v ← A.pop_f irst() if is_controlled(v) then e ← find_control_edge(G, v) (v, w) ← e if w / ∈ D then 4 s(w) ← s(v) • sgn(e) s(v) ← 0 D ← D ∪ w A.append(w) continue end end forall {e = (u, w) ∈ E|u = v} do if w / ∈ D then 9 s(w) ← s(u) • sgn(e) D ← D ∪ w A.append(w) end end end forall v ∈ V do if s(v) = {} then s(v) ← 0 end end
div.p: example to explain how an effect matrix can be interpreted.

Each row of the effect matrix represents the expected qualitative reaction (increase, decrease, unaffected) of a system variable to a specific action. In the case-study, each element in the set of actions

describes an action that a human operator could execute to manipulate the four-tank system presented in Section 5.4.4. For the action γ + 1 , which indicates and increase of the three-way valve position γ 1 , the effect matrix indicates an expected reaction of the process that features an increase of the variables h 3 , v 2 and γ 1 and a decrease of h 4 and v 1 , while h 1 , h 2 and γ 2 are expected to remain unaffected. This example illustrates that the effect matrix encodes all expected effects of an action, which allows the consideration of potentially undesired side-effects during planning.

Considering that the effect matrix is derived from a purely qualitative model of the system, it is clear that it does not include any information about the relative effect magnitudes or temporal information. The indications that h 3 increases and h 4 decreases for the action γ + 1 for instance, do not specify that h 3 increases just as much as h 4 decreases. It is only specified that the variables will change in opposing direction, without any additional information. It is further not specified which variable will start changing faster after the initiation of the action. In fact, the effect matrix in the case-study only encodes information about the steady-state response of the system, meaning that the indication of an increase of a variable implies that the steady-state that is reached after an action is taken is higher than the variable's state prior to the action. Deviations that are part of the transient response to an action are not considered.

div.head: Planning formulation
div.p: The effect matrix describes the expected qualitative transition of states after the execution of an action. Considering both qualitative and quantitative general planning formulations as presented by LaValle ( 2006), the effect matrix can be categorized as an element of a state-transition function. In order to describe a complete planning framework, the definition of further framework elements is required. The contribution presented in Appendix E defines all elements of a planning framework in such a way that the resulting planning formulation mimics a human operators approach to planning. The state space, which includes all configurations that the system can assume, contains all observable or manipulable system variables. The action space contains all actions that a human operator can execute to influence the process configuration. The state transition function assumes a quantitative change in the direction indicated by the effect that is encoded in the qualitative effect matrix. It has to be noted that this state transition function introduces a significant degree of implicit uncertainty, because it utilizes the qualitative information in the effect matrix for quantitative calculations. In order to address this, any planning method that utilizes the presented framework will have to use frequent process feedback to account for the uncertainty introduced in each planning stage. In order to evaluate the effect of potential state transitions, a cost function is defined that must satisfy the property that it produces decreasing costs with increased proximity to a desired goal configuration. The remaining elements of the planning framework, listed in Appendix E, conform to their generic definition in the planning framework for quantitative planning under uncertainty presented by LaValle (2006).

div.head: Case-study
div.p: The presented planning framework is tested on a case-study featuring the quadruple tank system shown in Fig. 5.11. The system consists of four connected water tanks with water levels h 1 -h 4 . The distribution of water in the four tanks is regulated through the positions of two three-way valves γ 1 and γ 2 , which are manually controlled. The water levels h 1 and h 2 are subject to closed loop control via the manipulated pump voltages v 1 and v 2 . A comprehensive description of the system and the implemented control architecture is provided by Johansson and Nunes (2000). The causal-model of the system is shown in Fig. 5.12. Control-edges, which do not represent a physical causal relation between system variables, but rather the information flow due to implemented control structures, are highlighted in green to indicate that propagations through these edges is treated differently by the propagation Algorithm 1. The result of state propagation, considering eight potential actions (increase or decrease of set-points for h 1 , h 2 , γ 1 , γ 2 ), yields the effect matrix that encodes the predicted qualitative system response to the mentioned actions, shown in Eq. 5.5. The integration of the shown effect matrix into the presented planning framework is utilized together with a greedy planner in order to run a closed-loop simulation of multiple system re-configuration scenarios. A generic change in operating condition (Fig. 5.13) and the re-configuration after a partial failure of pump one (Fig. 5.14) are investigated and illustrate the feasibility of the approach, although concerns regarding the planning performance and its high dependency on accurate feedback are raised in the conclusion in Appendix E. It must further be pointed out that while the closed loop application of the planning framework produced promising results for the case-study, the desired application of the framework is operator support, which will most likely not require the planning framework to operate in closed-loop. Its intended application is rather the suggestion of a list of feasible operator control actions. It is assumed, that human operators are capable of choosing appropriate action magnitudes by leveraging their process knowledge, if they are supplied with a short list of action candidates. The benefit of the framework would thus be to streamline the reasoning process by shortlisting potential actions for the operators to execute. In such scenarios, concerns regarding closed loop performance are less relevant.

div.head: Summary
div.p: The overview of qualitative and quantitative propagation strategies for causal models clarifies the implicit design choices that are made with the application of specific propagation algorithms. The benefits of nondeterministic propagation for diagnosis and deterministic propagation for planning are pointed out. For causal diagnosis, it is shown that the consideration of expected process behaviour that cannot be observed can improve diagnostic performance compared to appraoches that only consider the ability to explain observed deviations. The investigation of causal model-based planning illustrates that the inclusion of qualitative state transition functions into quantitative frameworks is feasible, as long as the implicit uncertainty that is introduced is considered. The results for the presented case-studies are promising.

div.head: CHAPTER 6
div.p: Development framework for operator support Throughout the development of the methods presented in the previous chapters, the lack of realistic case-studies has been a restricting factor. This section discusses the difficulties regarding the development and availability of suitable test frameworks for plant-wide diagnosis and action planning and presents two contributions, a dataset and a simulator, that address the discussed issues.

div.head: Required framework resources
div.p: Testing plant-wide operator support systems requires realistic test cases and process data. For counteraction planning, it is further most beneficial to have the ability to run open-and closed loop simulations. The following sections discuss the requirements for test cases, process data and simulators that have to be fulfilled in order to provide useful tools for the development of operator support systems. The presented simulation and data resources are necessities that must be available in addition to a causal process model of a system if realistic tests are to be performed.

div.head: Test cases
div.p: The main application of operator support systems using causal-models as presented in this thesis is plant-wide on-line diagnosis and counteraction planning. Realistic testcases that feature faults with plant-wide impact are paramount in order to properly test both applications. Specifically, this means that it is not sufficient to have access to a large amount of process and event data, but that it is further required to have data specifically for those events in which a plant-wide operator support system would be beneficial. Additionally, the analysis of complex fault scenarios requires profound system understanding, so that the proper development of test-cases can typically only be performed in collaboration with process engineers and control-room operators, who can provide feedback about the desired output of an automated support system at different stages of plant operation. If access to process experts is not possible or can't be achieved to the necessary degree, it is vital to choose a process that is documented so comprehensively that no uncertainty about the process behaviour and its reactions to introduced faults and potential operator actions remains. To investigate counteraction planning, it is further a minimal requirement that it is known which actions are reasonable for a support system to suggest at different stages of the fault and alarm progression.

div.head: Process data
div.p: Process data in the form of datasets is primarily useful for testing fault-diagnosis methods, since fault-diagnosis is often achieved through pure process monitoring without process interference. Datasets have the additional benefit that they provide simple and fast access to the required data, as opposed to simulators that usually require significantly more effort for setups and data generation. Considering this, datasets present the ideal framework for initial method testing and calibration, for which a certain amount of reliable process data with limited variety is required. The main drawback of using only datasets for method development is, naturally, that only open-loop tests can be run.

In addition to the size and the operational conditions contained in a dataset, the data content is most relevant. On-line fault diagnosis typically requires either quantitative process data from sensor readings or actuator settings or at least qualitative event data, typically from alarm and event logs. While a qualitative estimate of the process condition is often sufficient for qualitative causal graph based diagnosis, quantitative measurements enable a holistic analysis of the process behaviour under nominal and faulty conditions and should thus be preferred.

div.head: Simulators
div.p: The main benefit of simulators over datasets is the ability to customize. Datasets will often be sufficient for initial testing, but most datasets are not complete enough to cover all edge cases that are required to evaluate a methods performance. Simulators on the other hand enable the user to setup simulation scenarios that are designed to test specific properties of a method. Another benefit of simulators is the ability to test methods that actively influence the plant condition, such as control-schemes and active operator support systems. One of the main requirements for simulators is that their interface enables the simple and straight-forward simulation of relevant simulation cases. This is especially relevant for operator support system development, since some frequently used open-source simulators enable the simulation of interesting and relevant processes, but do not provide a suitable simulation interface. This issue will be discussed in detail in Section 6.2.4.

div.head: Tennessee Eastman process
div.p: In order to build an open-source framework that is specifically designed to facilitate research into on-line operator support, the Tennessee Eastman process (TEP) was selected based on a couple of criteria. First, TEP is sufficiently complex to warrant the application of plant-wide fault diagnosis and counteraction schemes, while being sufficiently well researched to enable a thorough investigation of the process behaviour by a moderately sized research team. Featuring more than 80 instrumented process variables and 28 pre-defined fault scenarios with plant wide impact, TEP is significantly more complex than most case-studies featured in the literature for causal process analysis mentioned in Section 3. The fact that is has been part of the public domain since its initial publication by Downs and Vogel (1993) and that it has been researched extensively since then has yielded extensive documentation of the process behaviour during nominal and faulty operation however, which enables a thorough analysis. Its extensive use in multiple chemical engineering research disciplines, including statistical process monitoring and FDI should facilitate the adoption for causal model-based fault diagnosis. Additionally, efforts to use TEP as a benchmark for causal-model based analysis have already been undertaken, e.g. by Suresh et al. (2019), Ma and Li (2017) and Kirchhübel and Jørgensen (2019). Lastly, existing datasets and simulators provide an ideal foundation for the development of an extended framework that is tailored to the application of decision support systems.

div.head: Process description
div.p: TEP is a chemical production process that produces two liquid product components G and H from four gaseous reactants A, C, D and E with an additional inert B and a byproduct F through four irreversible, exothermic reactions:
div.formula: A(g) + C(g) + D(g) → G(liq) (Product 1) A(g) + C(g) + E(g) → H(liq) (Product 2) A(g) + E(g) → F (liq) (Byproduct) 3D(g) → F (liq) (Byproduct)
div.p: The process layout is shown in Fig. 6.1. The main process units are the reactor, product condenser, vapor-liquid separator, recycle compressor and product stripper. An interesting asset of TEP is that it features different modes of operation, which are distinguished by the production rates and product mass ratios (Downs and Vogel, 1993). Further, an operating cost function based on feed component and energy costs related to the process operating point is defined by Downs and Vogel (1993), which enables the investigation of optimal operating conditions for the introduced operating modes and other configurations. Ricker (1995) presents optimal operating conditions for all production modes and further provides corresponding optimal set-points, listed in Table 6.1, for the distributed control-scheme presented in Ricker (1996). During the revision, two major aspects were considered.

On the one hand the algorithms and structure of the code were revised, so as to adapt it to the structure of the simulation loop. On the other hand the model was extended in terms of additional outputs, new process disturbances and so forth.

div.head: Changes to the simulation model
div.p: With regard to the code the following three objectives were accomplished:

• Revision of the generation of random numbers and the update mechanism of the process disturbances • Revision of the execution of tefunc() in order to adapt the program to the needs of the respective step of the simulation loop • Revision of the model's data structure Revision of the disturbance generation As stated in the preceding section, the differences of the simulation results can be traced back to the usage of the random number generator. Thus the revised model is equipped with two random number generators for both the measurement noise and the process disturbances by adding a second state to the existing random state. Now, there is one state for the generation of the measurement noise and another for the generation of the process disturbances. Hence, the number concerns the recalculation of the coefficients of the disturbance polynomials themselves. Since the time points of the recalculation, which are determined during the previous recalculation, are not synchronized with the simulation calculations, the actual recalculation will be done during the subsequent call of tefunc() (relative to the determined time of the recalculation). Due to the program flow of each solver, it is possible that one solver recalculates the coefficients during the inner loop, whereas another solver does this recalculation only when the next major time step has been reached. As long as only one disturbance process needs to be recalculated, there are no problems. But as soon as two or more recalculations are needed between two major time steps, the recalculation order may vary. This again results in different simulation results. Thus the recalculation algorithm was altered to ensure that the order is based on the time of the recalculation and not on the index of the process disturbance. With this second modification the generation of the process disturbances is completely independent of the choice of the solver.

div.head: Execution of the main-function
div.p: As shown in Fig. 2, every time the outputs or derivatives of the simulation model are determined, the whole model (i.e. code) is executed. However, this is unnecessary since the derivatives are not needed when the outputs are determined and vice versa. Furthermore, the process data, which describe the process's current state by means of temperatures, levels, etc. of the process units, need to be calculated only once during a (minor/major) time step. The process data are determined based on the states of the model. That is, only Table 6.1: Setpoints for the TEP control-scheme by Ricker (1996) for optimal steadystate operation as defined by Ricker (1995).

div.head: Test cases
div.p: As mentioned in Section 6.1.1, one of the most important assets of a development framework for operator decision support is the ability to simulate realistic test-cases with plant-wide impact. The initial distribution of the TEP simulator by Downs and Vogel (1993) allowed the activation of 20 process faults. The extended simulator presented by Bathelt et al. (2015) adds eight additional process faults and allows all process faults to be simulated at chosen fault magnitudes. The 28 available process faults, listed in Table 6.2, can be separated into the types Step, Random variation and Sticking. For most causal model-based analysis, the faults of type Step are most interesting, as these lead to persistent deviations in process behaviour. The existing fault-scenarios provide a very good foundation for plant-wide fault analysis and should yield sufficient data for initial testing for causal model-based analysis.

div.head: Datasets
div.p: Existing datasets (Braatz, 2020;Chen, 2019;Rieth et al., 2017) provide relatively complete data for basic testing of fault-detection and identification research, with a focus on operating mode 1. Considering potential applications of TEP for alarm analysis, Manca (2020) additionally provide alarm data related to the step-change faults of TEP in mode 1. Two of the main drawbacks of existing data for TEP is that only one of six operating modes is considered and that neither transitions between operating modes nor between different set-point configurations in the vicinity of the operating modes are included in the data. This poses two issues regarding the analysis based on existing data. Firstly, the performance of quantitative faultdetection schemes might be overestimated, because the definition of the nominal operating condition is very narrow, since the only included nominal condition is set to exactly match the ideal operation of mode 1. It can thus not be definitively stated whether applied fault-detection schemes can distinguish between nominal changes in the operating condition and actual process faults. The second drawback is that current datasets include no information about the process reaction to intentional changes, such as those that could be issued by control-room operators in the form of set-point changes. This means that current datasets simply do not allow the investigation of an operators means to supervise and control the process.

To address these issues, the contribution in Appendix A introduces a new dataset for TEP, which includes all six operating modes as well as dynamic set-point changes and mode transitions. The goal of the publication presented in Appendix A is to provide a more realistic representation of real plant operation data, including a nominal range of operation rather than a single operating point. The data can further be used to validate causal-models through the investigation of trends for fault-scenarios and set-point changes, allowing both the expected process behaviour resulting from malfunctions as well as intended operating procedures to be validated.

div.head: Simulators
div.p: Existing simulators (Bathelt et al., 2015;Braatz, 2020;Downs and Vogel, 1993;Gins et al., 2014) enable the simulation of TEP using either MATLAB/Simulink or a set of FORTRAN routines. The most complete TEP simulator prior to the contribution presented in Appendix B was introduced by Bathelt et al. (2015), is implemented in MATLAB/Simulink and allows simple setups and simulations for TEP in operating modes one and three. Set-point changes and the extraction of an extended set of process variables require modifications of the presented simulation model and data must be exported from nested structures in the MATLAB workspace.

The investigation of the currently available simulation options for TEP leads to the following conclusions: The simulator by Bathelt et al. (2015) currently provides the most complete simulation interface and the most options for customization, regarding the activation of process faults, additional process variables and measurement noise. The only true drawback of the simulator is that it provides no user-friendly interface, which greatly reduces its utility.

In order to improve the simulators utility, the contribution presented in Appendix B introduces a Python wrapper for the simulator by Bathelt et al. (2015), which provides an interface that provides the functionalities that are required for elaborate process simulations, including set-point changes with different profiles, faultactivation and interactive-simulation capabilities. In addition, it facilitates data-usage by providing save-and reload functionalities to commonly used data formats. The main functionalities that make up the interface of the presented simulator (pyTEP), are shown in Fig. 6

div.head: Summary
div.p: The presented dataset and simulator for the Tennessee Eastman process provide the means to to test diagnosis and counteraction methods using a realistic case-study. The developed simulation interface is especially setup in such a way that the integration of methods for counteraction planning into the existing simulation environment is facilitated. The presented resources provide a simple and openly accessible simulation framework that is much closer to industrial standards than previously utilized casestudies and can thus help to evaluate the utility of causal analysis for real industrial applications. It must be noted that testing causal diagnosis and action planning with the presented simulator will require the integration of a causal model for the Tennessee Eastman process. To this end, existing causal models of the process (Kirchhübel and Jørgensen, 2019;Suresh et al., 2019) could be utilized to facilitate the integration.

div.head: CHAPTER 7 Conclusion
div.p: The presented PhD project contributes to the development of causal model-based decision support systems. Based on a survey of the state of the art as well as experiences gathered during the project execution, two open issues have been identified; the lack of contextualization of existing causal analysis methods and the lack of sufficiently complex and easily accessible case-studies. The contextualization of causal analysis is addressed by means of a review and evaluation of existing causal propagation approaches. The focus is on the significance of different propagation techniques in relation to diagnosis and planning applications, rather than technical specifics regarding the propagation algorithms. Based on the evaluation, a nondeterministic propagation strategy is identified as most beneficial for diagnosis applications. The utility of the approach is tested in combination with a novel cause ranking strategy that considers decision-variables that were identified as relevant by experienced control-room operators. It is shown that considering the absence of expected deviations as an additional decision variable for cause ranking can improve results if applied in combination with nondeterministic propagation.

Regarding planning applications, the utilization of nondeterministic propagation procedures is rejected in favor of either retracted propagation or semi-quantitative propagation, because the potential inability to consider side-effects of chosen actions when nondeterministic propagation is applied is evaluated as undesirable. It is pointed out that nondeterministic propagation for planning can produce good results if applied for an identification of potential action candidates, but that its utility for action-candidate ranking is limited. The utility of deterministic causal propagation strategies for planning is extended through the introduction of a formalized framework that directly utilizes the output of causal model-based propagation and enables closed-loop planning. It is further identified that the automatic model-based generation of planning procedures requires the inclusion of actions that should be considered for planning in the model definition, which potentially necessitates extensions of existing methodologies for causal process modeling. In this context, an extension of Multilevel Flow modeling is introduced that enables the explicit representation of a human operators means to interfere with the modeled system.

The lack of relevant case-studies is addressed through the development of a dataset and simulation framework that facilitates the investigation of complex operating scenarios for the Tennessee Eastman process. A review of current simulation resources reveals that the main factor that inhibits the utilization of existing simulators for causal analysis is not a lack of functionality, but rather a lack of a suitable simulation interface. This issue is addressed by the developed Python simulator for the Tennessee Eastman process, which provides a comprehensive interface in addition to new functionalities that enable the integration of diagnosis and planning applications.

div.head: Fulfillment of the research objectives
div.p: The direct association of the contents of the thesis to the specific research objectives listed in Section 1.2 is provided below.

In order to identify common features of MFM and other causal models, the publication presented in Appendix D presents a direct mapping between MFM models and signed directed graphs, which provide a generic representation for causal analysis. The presented method enables the direct comparison of any causal model that can be represented as a graph to MFM.

Extensions of the modeling language that enable MFM based planning are directly addressed by the publication presented in Appendix F. It is identified that the main element that MFM is missing in order to fully enable model-based action planning is the explicit definition of possible actions. The newly introduced MFM patterns and logic for MFM control functions enable the description of an operators means to influence the modeled process through controller settings and manual adjustments.

Chapter 5 provides information about the utility of causal propagation strategies for different applications in diagnosis and planning and extends causal diagnosis methods to improve diagnostic accuracy. The improvements within diagnosis applications are related to the investigation of new decision criteria, which are first introduced and further discussed in Appendix C. The contribution in Appendix G further initiates the discussion how causal analysis can be applied in systems with little instrumentation, specifically related to the utility of methods that have proven useful for heavily instrumented systems. It is concluded that benefits for lightly instrumented systems mainly comprise the identification of plausible root-cause and action candidates rather than automatically generated, sufficiently accurate candidate rankings.

The contribution in Appendix E directly addresses the development of a causal model-based planning framework. Considering potential future extensions that feature quantitative data, a semi-quantitative planning formulation is introduced that incorporates the information obtained from causal analysis in form of an effect matrix.
The development of a test framework for process analysis is achieved through the contributions presented in Appendix A and Appendix B.

A demonstration of the application of the developed methods in suitable casestudies is included in most of the presented publications. Case studies that further show industrial significance are included in Appendix C and Appendix F, which investigate fault scenarios generated by a realistic simulator for a pressurized water reactor, and in Appendix D, which utilizes the Tennessee Eastman process for comparisons of MFM to other causal models.

div.head: Outlook
div.p: Considering the state of the art and the newly introduced contributions, the most relevant open challenge related to causal modeling appears to be the evaluation of existing methods in industrial settings. As one of the advertised benefits of qualitative process representations is improved scalability compared to quantitative modeling approaches, it is essential to prove that the presented methods, which have shown promise for moderately sized processes, do actually have the potential to scale to industrial size. Utilizing the new Tennessee Eastman simulator can provide a good starting point that enables tests using a process that is already significantly more complex than many cases studied in literature, but eventually it will be required to evaluate methods using real-life industrial data. The collaborations with industry in the petrochemical sector that are enabled by the Danish Hydrocarbon Research and Technology Centre at DTU provide interesting opportunities. However, a joint development effort involving multiple parties in an academic setting would be facilitated by the availability of a public test framework at industrial scale. The integration of current causal analysis methods for processes of such scale will further require the development of comprehensive analysis tools for causal models that features both model-building and online reasoning functionalities. Such tools are actively developed by the group of Automation and Control at the Technical University of Denmark and its industrial partners.

div.head: A.1 Introduction
div.p: The recent decades have seen a major push towards the optimization of process operations. Along with this go multiple areas of research within the process monitoring and fault-detection and isolation (FDI) communities. The existing approaches can broadly be classified into model-based, data-driven and hybrid approaches. Modelbased approaches based on first-principle models require a high degree of a priori knowledge about the system under investigation. Their application to large-scale C. Reinartz et al. (2021c). "An extended Tennessee Eastman simulation dataset for faultdetection and decision support systems." In: Computers & Chemical Engineering. doi: https : //doi.org/10.1016/j.compchemeng.2021.107281.

systems can thus often be challenging, especially if parts of these systems are subject to uncertainty. Data-driven approaches use available process measurements to classify the operation of a system. Typically, intervals during which the operation is known to be normal are used as training data to characterize the nominal operation of the process so that faults can be detected as deviations from the learned nominal process characteristics. Fault isolation using data-driven approaches often requires additional data representing the characteristic behaviour of the process while it is subjected to faults. To compare performances of different FDI approaches, realistic benchmark cases are required.

The Tennessee Eastman process (TEP) has been extensively used for this purpose since the initial publication by Downs and Vogel, 1993. It provides a benchmark case that can be used to investigate most challenges continuous processes present. In the original publication, Downs and Vogel, 1993 list plant-wide control design, multivariate control, optimization, predictive control, adaptive control, nonlinear control, process diagnostics and educational purposes as potential applications of the simulator. Different control-designs (Larsson et al., 2001;Lyman and Georgakis, 1995;Ricker, 1996;Ricker and Lee, 1995) were proposed in the years following the initial publication of the process and others have been added at a later stage (Molina et al., 2011). Many recent publications involving the Tennessee Eastman process focus on fault detection using classical statistics or machine learning based approaches. Arunthavanathan et al., 2020 presents an unsupervised learning method for the detection and diagnosis of unknown fault-conditions by integrating a unary classification algorithm for fault-detection with a dynamic shallow neural network for fault-classification. Han et al., 2020 iteratively optimize the number of hidden layers in a Long shortterm memory (LSTM) network to achieve higher diagnostic accuracy. Maran Beena and Pani, 2020 apply Gaussian process regression (GRP)-based process monitoring to the Tennessee Eastman process and investigate the effect of GPR hyper parameters on monitoring efficiency, while Fezai et al., 2020 combine GPR with a generalized likelihood ratio test. The performance of Kantorovich Distance Independent Component Analysis is investigated by Kini and Madakyaru, 2020, who also provide a comparison to other frequently used statistical monitoring techniques. Dong and Qin, 2018 present a fault-diagnosis method based on deep convolutional neural networks to detect 20 process faults. Ragab et al., 2018 apply a machine-learning based classification technique called logical analysis of data to extract interpretable patterns linked to physical phenomena to the base case of TEP. Bakdi and Kouadri, 2018 presents a process monitoring scheme that is based on the integration of univariate and multivariate statistical analysis methods by using an adaptive threshold scheme instead of conventional fixed control limits. Zhang and Zhao, 2017 present a deep belief network for the detection of process faults in TEP and compare the performance of one-class-one-network (OCON) and one-variable-one-network (OVON) architectures regarding training complexity and classification accuracy. Recent years have also seen a number of publications using the Tennessee Eastman process within the field of operations research and the design of decision support systems. These publications focus on methods that yield interpretable results for process diagnostics and operation, capable of explaining the recommendations and decisions of AI-based systems. Venkatasubramanian, 2019 stresses the need for such systems for faultdiagnosis and hazard analysis. Suresh et al., 2019 present a semi-automated method for the generation of hierarchical causal models of continuous processes using transfer entropy as a causality measure, while Mori et al., 2014 use a Bayesian approach to generate a causal network from process data. Gao et al., 2016 present an approach to extract meaningful patterns highlighting the relations of variables across streams and units using sparse principal component analysis. He et al., 2014 present a hybrid fault-diagnosis method that integrates reconstruction-based multivariate contribution analysis with fuzzy signed directed graphs for root-cause analysis. Further research opportunities, especially with regard to the possibilities opened up by a new simulator by Bathelt et al., 2015, are outlined by Capaci et al., 2018. The amount of publications featuring TEP in recent years is a good indicator for its continued relevance in various research communities. A hindrance to the comparison of the contributions published since 2015 is that the presented methods and performance analysis are conducted based on different process data for TEP, however. Some contributions use the simulator by Bathelt et al., 2015 to generate process data while others utilize existing datasets, which are generated using older simulators and which feature different control structures for TEP. In order to facilitate the use of data from the simulator by Bathelt et al., 2015, it is necessary to provide a reference dataset generated using said simulator, which makes use of the newly introduced functionalities and provides a proper benchmark for future research, just as currently available datasets provide a reference benchmark for previous iterations of TEP simulators.

div.head: A.1.1 Existing simulators
div.p: The original model, consisting of a set of Fortran routines, was presented by Downs and Vogel, 1993 and can be found on various sources online. It describes the openloop behaviour of the process, which is unstable. The repository by Braatz, 2020 includes a simulator based on a set of Fortran routines that implements the control scheme presented by Lyman and Georgakis, 1995, which allows the simulation of 20 process faults at full fault-magnitude for the base case. Sample and fault-activation times can be adjusted as required and seeds for the random generator can be set explicitly. While most of the datasets currently used for fault detection and diagnosis are based on this simulator, it has not been extended as other simulators mentioned below and by now offers fewer options for modifications of the simulation. Gins et al., 2014 integrate the Tennessee Eastman model into the RAYMOND simulation package, thus extending simulation capabilities to facilitate the inclusion of input variations, different noise signatures and additional process faults. Other implementations of control-schemes that stabilize the process are available at the Tennessee Eastman Challenge Archive (Ricker, 2020). These include a model-predictive control (MPC) approach by Ricker and Lee, 1995 and a decentralized control approach from Ricker, 1996. Additionally, a MPC approach for a simplified model of the Tennessee Eastman process from Ricker, 1993 and a summary of optimal steady states of the TEP for the six operating modes, presented in Ricker, 1995, are included. Most notably, the Challenge Archive includes a revised model of the TEP by Bathelt et al., 2015. The revised model includes implementations of three control strategies. The models labeled Multiloop_mode1 and Multiloop_mode3 implement the decentralized control strategy by Ricker, 1996, without and with override loops, respectively, while Multiloop_Skoge implements the control strategy presented by Larsson et al., 2001. The revised model introduces multiple significant improvements compared to previous versions (Bathelt et al., 2015). Most importantly, it remedies an issue where the simulation results show a dependency on the chosen solver and simulation timeincrement in cases where disturbances of the type random variation are activated. Further, eight new process disturbances (IDV 21-28 in Table A.3) of the type random variation as well as the option to scale the magnitude of disturbances are added. The revised model additionally includes an extended set of process measurements as well as the option to log internal process variables.

div.head: A.1.2 Existing Datasets
div.p: While the investigation of the efficacy of different control schemes requires direct use of a TEP simulator, most process analysis and FDI research only requires a sufficiently complete database of simulation results for a given control scheme. The obvious benefits of a database are direct data access and the ability to compare different methods using identical baselines, meaning identical data. Braatz, 2020 provides training and test data for 21 simulated faults, which are summarized in Chiang et al., 2000. Each fault and the normal process operation in mode 1 of the process are simulated with a sampling rate of 3 minutes. Training data files contain runs of 25 hours and testing data files runs of 48 hours, resulting in 500 and 960 observations for each run, respectively. A similar data set, though updated more recently, is provided by Chen, 2019. The main drawback of the data provided by Braatz, 2020 is that each fault case is represented by a single simulation, providing a single noise signature for each given run and not allowing evaluations of performance metrics such as the average run-length that require multiple simulations of the same event. This issue is addressed by Rieth et al., 2017, who simulate healthy data and the process faults with the same simulation setup as Braatz, 2020 (sampling rate of 3 minutes for a duration of 25 hours for training and 48 hours for test data, respectively), but run each simulation 500 times with independent, non-overlapping seeds for the random number generator, allowing a thorough analysis of the different process faults in operating mode 1. Manca, 2020 provides reference data for alarm management studies of TEP in Mode 1 including simulation data and corresponding alarm data for the seven pre-defined process faults of TEP that can be described as step changes. Using the simulator by Bathelt et al., 2015, these faults are simulated at different fault-magnitudes. For investigation of faults at full magnitude in production mode 1, Rieth et al., 2017 currently provides the most complete dataset, viewed from a statistical process control perspective, because it provides multiple simulation runs for identical simulation settings with different seeds for the random number generator for 20 process faults.

div.head: A.1.3 Novelty and Contribution
div.p: We present a new reference dataset for the Tennessee Eastman Process that extends existing reference data in both scope, regarding its potential applications, and scale, in terms of the amount of generated data. Contrary to previously presented data, which focused exclusively on a specific operating mode of the process (Mode 1), we present simulations for all 28 process faults that are part of the latest TEP simulator by Bathelt et al., 2015 for all six operating modes that were originally presented by Downs and Vogel, 1993. We further increase the simulation run-time for all simulations to 100 hours, so that it is guaranteed that both transient as well as stationary effects of the simulated faults are captured in each run. Additionally, we provide a benchmark for multivariate fault detection performance for the presented dataset using average run length of PCA-based Hotelling T 2 and Q charts as the performance metric for all modes and simulated faults.

In addition to simulations for the purpose of developing and testing the performance of fault detection and isolation schemes, we present data that can be used to test the robustness of such schemes for processes with varying nominal operating conditions. Further, the effects of deliberate set-points changes for all six operating modes as well as transitions between the specified operating modes using different transients are simulated. Making use of the extended simulation capabilities of the simulator presented by Bathelt et al., 2015, the logging data is extended to include 53 additional data points for each time step, representing additional process measurements and internal process variables.

div.head: A.2 Tennessee Eastman Process
div.p: The process involves the production of two liquid product components G and H from four gaseous reactants A, C, D and E with an additional inert B and a byproduct F. The reaction system consists of four exothermic and irreversible reactions which are described by:
div.formula: A(g) + C(g) + D(g) → G(liq) (Product 1) A(g) + C(g) + E(g) → H(liq) (Product 2) A(g) + E(g) → F (liq) (Byproduct) 3D(g) → F (liq) (Byproduct)
div.p: The five major process units are the reactor, product condenser, vapor-liquid separator, recycle compressor and product stripper. The reactants A, D and E flow to the reactor from upstream. The reactor output stream, consisting of products and unreacted feed, is fed into a condenser and subsequent vapor-liquid unit. Condensed components enter the product stripper where the remaining reactants are separated from the products G and H and non-condensed components are recycled to the reactor feed through the recycle compressor. During the revision, two major aspects were considered.

On the one hand the algorithms and structure of the code were revised, so as to adapt it to the structure of the simulation loop. On the other hand the model was extended in terms of additional outputs, new process disturbances and so forth.

div.head: Changes to the simulation model
div.p: With regard to the code the following three objectives were accomplished:

• Revision of the generation of random numbers and the update mechanism of the process disturbances • Revision of the execution of tefunc() in order to adapt the program to the needs of the respective step of the simulation loop • Revision of the model's data structure Revision of the disturbance generation As stated in the preceding section, the differences of the simulation results can be traced back to the usage of the random number generator. Thus the revised model is equipped with two random number generators for both the measurement noise and the process disturbances by adding a second state to the existing random state. Now, there is one state for the generation of the measurement noise and another for the generation of the process disturbances. Hence, the number concerns the recalculation of the coefficients of the disturbance polynomials themselves. Since the time points of the recalculation, which are determined during the previous recalculation, are not synchronized with the simulation calculations, the actual recalculation will be done during the subsequent call of tefunc() (relative to the determined time of the recalculation). Due to the program flow of each solver, it is possible that one solver recalculates the coefficients during the inner loop, whereas another solver does this recalculation only when the next major time step has been reached. As long as only one disturbance process needs to be recalculated, there are no problems. But as soon as two or more recalculations are needed between two major time steps, the recalculation order may vary. This again results in different simulation results. Thus the recalculation algorithm was altered to ensure that the order is based on the time of the recalculation and not on the index of the process disturbance. With this second modification the generation of the process disturbances is completely independent of the choice of the solver.

div.head: Execution of the main-function
div.p: As shown in Fig. 2, every time the outputs or derivatives of the simulation model are determined, the whole model (i.e. code) is executed. However, this is unnecessary since the derivatives are not needed when the outputs are determined and vice versa. Furthermore, the process data, which describe the process's current state by means of temperatures, levels, etc. of the process units, need to be calculated only once during a (minor/major) time step. The process data are determined based on the states of the model. That is, only

div.head: A.3.1 Simulation groups
div.p: The provided data can be separated into three different groups. The majority of the simulations belong to the simulation group for statistical process monitoring and other fault-detection and identification approaches. Simulations in this group consist of a run-in, during which the process operates nominally, followed by the introduction of a single fault into the system, which results in a reaction of the implemented control system and changed operating conditions and possibly an emergency shutdown of the plant. An example of a simulation from this simulation group is shown in Fig.

A.2, where the reaction of the process to the activation of the fault IDV2, described in Table A.3, are presented. Considering the six operating modes in combination with the 28 process faults, the single fault simulations feature 168 different setups that are investigated. In addition to the investigation of the process faults at full magnitudes, we further simulate all faults at magnitudes 25%, 50% and 75%, leading to 672 different simulation setups. In order to create a dataset that is viable for the development and testing of statistical process monitoring approaches, each setup is simulated 200 times at 100% fault magnitude and 100 times at 25%, 50% and 75% fault magnitude, resulting in 500 simulations of each process fault and 84000 fault simulations overall.

The second group contains simulations that feature deliberate set-point changes introduced to the six nominal operating modes. These set-point changes mimic the effect of actions performed by human operators by considering the 12 direct external access points, listed in Table A.2, to the Tennessee Eastman process for the used control scheme. Following a run-in as in the first simulation group, single set-point variations in a 15% interval around the original value are introduced to the system. Given the chosen increment of set-point variations of 5% of the original value, this results in 7 simulation runs for each set-point and thus 504 simulation runs considering the six modes, 12 set-points and 20 magnitudes. Each set-point change is further simulated with different transition profiles; a step-profile and ramp profiles with ramping durations of 0, 10, 20, 30 and 40 hours. We see two main uses of this simulation group. In the context of statistical process monitoring, it allows the investigation of the robustness to slightly changing, though nominal, operating conditions that should not be classified as faulty operations. This addresses the fact, that many currently presented approaches perform very well, as long as the nominal operating conditions doesn't vary too much. Especially for the Tennessee Eastman Process, most presented approaches are trained on a clearly defined, single operating point (Mode 1), and every process configuration that deviates is classified as a fault.

Because process operating conditions can not be specified that precisely in many real applications, we believe that it is necessary to provide data for nominal operations that features more variation, including multiple feasible operating points as well as dynamic transitions featuring ramp and step profiles between such stationary operating conditions. In addition to its application to statistical process monitoring, the second group of simulations can be used for the investigation of the means of externally influencing the Tennessee Eastman process via the control set-points in the presence of closed loop control, mimicking a human control room operators means of influencing the process. Such investigations can be useful for research concerned with decision support systems for operators, as active decision support tools could propose the set-point changes in the provided simulation group as feasible measures in for example reconfiguration scenarios after activation of process faults.

The third simulation group contains simulations of transitions between the six operating modes, with ramp transition profiles for the respective set-points with ramping durations of 10, 20, 30 and 40 simulation hours. This group completes the data for nominal process operation, as any real process with six specified modes would also have to feature transitions between said modes.

div.head: A.3.2 Simulation parameters
div.p: Each simulation run is simulated for a duration of 100 simulation hours at a sampling rate of 3 minutes, resulting in 2000 observations. During the first 30 hours, the process is run in a nominal operating mode, meaning one of the six modes presented above. After 30 hours the process is subjected to either a process fault from the list presented in Table A.3 or a control-setpoint change. The final 70 simulation hours represent the reaction of TEP to the introduced change. Downs and Vogel, 1993 state that the process can show dynamic behaviour after a control-setpoint change for 24-48 hours before settling on a new stationary operating condition. Inspection of the dynamic behaviour of the process' reaction to setpoint changes shows that 48 hours is a very conservative measure and that a new stationary operating point is reached within 40 hours after the introduction of a deviation. Similarly, a transition time of 40 simulation hours is sufficient to capture the transient behaviour resulting from the presented process disturbances of the type 'Step'. Disturbances of the type 'Random Variation' and 'Sticking' affect the process behaviour continuously so that the process reaction can't be clearly separated into transient and stationary responses. Based on the analysis of maximum process response times, the intent behind the 70 simulation hours of fault simulation is that this interval can be split into 40 hours of simulation time which include the dynamic response and 30 hours of simulation time with a high certainty represent stationary process behaviour under changed operating conditions. This 30-40-30 split of the 100 simulation hours is applied to both fault simulations and setpoint variation runs.

div.head: A.3.3 Data content
div.p: Three different datasets are provided for each simulation run. The first dataset, labeled "processdata", contains information about simulation time, the original set of process measurements and the manipulated variables. This data, summarized in Table A.4, includes all variables that have been frequently used in statistical process control studies. The second dataset, labeled "additional_meas" contains the additional process measurements shown in Table A.5. These values correspond to the first model flag introduced in the simulator by Bathelt et al., 2015. In the third dataset, labeled "idv_monitoring", specific information about selected random disturbances is provided. This data, summarized in Table A.6, corresponds to the second model flag by Bathelt et al., 2015. It should be noted that the "idv_monitoring" data is only provided for simulations in which process faults of the type random variation (IDV 8-13, 16-18, 20-28) are active. It was decided to include the additional measurement points provided by Bathelt et al., 2015 in the data, because they provide an opportunity to study how a higher degree of instrumentation affects fault detection and identification in the process. The monitoring of the random-variation disturbances, for which the logged values are not affected by noise, makes it possible to study the effect of the disturbances in greater detail.

div.head: A.3.4 Storage format
