div.p: D Generation of Signed Directed Graphs Using Functional Models presented at the 5th IFAC Conference on Intelligent Control and Automation Sciences, 2019

div.head: D.5 Case Study
div.p: The Tennessee Eastman process is a well-known process from the chemical industries that was first introduced by Downs and Vogel (1993). It has since been used as a benchmark problem for studies in fault-diagnosis (Yin et al., 2012), state estimation (Ricker and Lee, 1995), control (Zerkaoui et al., 2010) The aim of this case study is to compare a SDG that was generated using a MFM model of the Tennessee Eastman reactor to a reference SDG presented by Ma and Li (2017) and reach conclusions about the merit of the method proposed in this article based on the consistency between the MFM model and the generated SDG on the one hand and the similarity between the generated and reference SDGs on the other hand. The MFM model used as a basis for the graph generation is displayed in Fig. D.9. It was designed from the knowledge represented in the flow sheet using the modeling strategy presented by Lind (2017). The graph shown in Fig. D.7 is the direct result of the application of the principles presented in Sections D.4 and D.4.1. The consistency of MFM and generated SDG is tested by comparing the results of single fault propagation applied to both graphs. To this end, all scenarios resulting from a single fault input are generated using the propagation rules for MFM and SDG, respectively. It is then verified that nodes referring to the same process variable have the same state in all corresponding scenarios. This test was successfully run for all single fault scenarios (positive and negative deviation of each process variable) of the generated Tennessee Eastman Reactor model. It is apparent that the generated (black edges) and reference (black and red edges) graphs are very similar. The automatically generated graph does not contain additional edges compared to the reference. The reference graph contains four edges and thus for causal relations which are not covered by the generated graph. It was expected that these relations would not be represented in the generated model, since they take the effect of the stripper and vapour-liquid separator into account, which have not been considered in the MFM model that focuses on the functionality of the reactor. It is noticeable that the generated graph does not feature any edges which imply "false" causal relations, which is important, since invalid causalities can lead to incorrect reasoning and thus impede the fault analysis. Process variable names are directly adopted from the used reference study conducted by Ma and Li (2017). The process is modelled using the MFM-modeling principles descibed by Lind (2017).

div.head: D.6 Conclusion
div.p: The conversion of functional process models to signed directed graphs is generally achieved by translating implicit causalities to explicit ones, as presented in Section D.4. Such an approach is realizable for many functional modeling concepts, e.g. some of those presented by Erden et al. (2008), indicating that the presented method is in principle applicable for other approaches than Multilevel Flow Modeling as well. Researchers focusing on signed directed graph based fault analysis profit from using functional models in two ways. They can use the existing modeling guidelines developed for the functional modeling concepts that are designed to identify causal structures in specific industrial applications. Following such guidelines ensures consistent model design and thereby consistent design of the signed directed graphs used for the analysis. In addition to that, the opportunity to express the diagnosis output in a functional modeling framework designed for the evaluation by process experts facilitates communication in the respective target industry. A major benefit for researchers in the field of functional modeling is that the extensively researched field of fault diagnosis using signed directed graphs becomes directly accessible. This provides the opportunity to integrate such research into the development of functional reasoning systems with minimal effort. The method presented in Section D.4 facilitates the addressed consistent model generation for processes in the chemical, petroleum and nuclear industries. Initial testing on the Tennessee Eastman process has yielded promising results, including a automatically generated, well-formulated signed directed graph model of the Tennessee Eastman reactor which closely matches models presented in literature. Further case studies on systems from the chemical and petroleum industries as well as further research on the integration of signed directed graphs into the Multilevel Flow Modeling concept are planned for the near future.

div.head: E.1 Introduction
div.p: The operation of large industrial plants involves the interaction between human operators and automated control systems. The goal is to ensure production on a high level of consistency, safety and economic efficiency that cannot be achieved by either manual or fully automatic control. Unit operations are commonly controlled using distributed control schemes, with Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) systems enabling human operators to issue process commands. In nominal operation, the operator configures the system for maximum profitability. In the event of abnormal system behaviour the operator ensures the return to safe operation or initiates the shut-down of the plant. Current trends towards increased automation and decreased human supervision of process plants challenge this established method of operation. Increased automation entails increased instrumentation and monitoring, which, in theory, improves plant supervision capabilities. In practice, the amount of monitoring exceeds what an operator can process, leading to cognitive overload that can result in slow or incorrect decision making, especially in unforeseen situations. Automated condition monitoring and decision support systems can be used to reduce the occurrence of such situations by providing contextual information that facilitates the decision making. The last decades have seen significant progress in both quantitative model-based and data-driven fault diagnosis, but the scalability of quantitative process models to plant-scale and the lack of interpretability of results generated from data-driven methods remain known drawbacks. The demand for methods that yield explainable results on a plant-scale requires re-evaluation and extension of approaches that were previously shown to be capable of satisfying these properties, such as causality-based diagnosis and reasoning systems (Venkatasubramanian, 2019).

Causal process models have been considered for root-cause analysis and process supervision for a long time (Leyval et al., 1994), and nowadays, improved automated generation and validation techniques enable their application for a wide range of processes. Suresh et al., 2019 presents the generation of causal models in form of hierarchically structured directed graphs based on transfer entropy, while Mori et al., 2014 uses a Bayesian model to identify optimal causal network structures for root-cause diagnosis. A method for semi-automated generation of causal functional models from existing documentation of plant topology in the form of P&ID diagrams is presented in Song et al., 2020. Yang et al., 2012 presents how cross-correlation and transfer entropy can be used to validate manually or semi-automated models using process data.

The development of applications utilizing causal models proceeded concurrently to the development of new modeling strategies with a strong focus on techniques for root-cause analysis of process faults. Mori et al., 2014, Wan et al., 2013and He et al., 2014 use causal graphs for fault detection and root-cause analysis of a chemical engineering benchmark process, highlighting the capability of causal models to diagnose faults for which no historic process data is available. The recent successes in the generation of causal models and their use in process diagnosis promotes an investigation of their further applicability for decision support, especially in areas where other approaches perform poorly, such as the automatic actuation and reconfiguration of complex processes with limited quantitative knowledge. A scheduling approach for coke gas systems based on a joint application of causal-models and least-squares support vector machines is proposed by Jin et al., 2018.

div.head: E.1.1 Novelty and contribution
div.p: The paper proposes a novel planning framework for the operation of continuous processes during transitions between steady-states, where automatic and manual control contribute to the regulation. A causal model in form of a signed directed graph is created to describe the qualitative knowledge about the impact of manual and automatic control actions onto the process variables. This is encoded in an effect matrix generated through an algorithm that propagates steady-state process responses to disturbances and deliberate state changes in the presence of control loops. A greedy planner is adopted to find the locally optimal operator action based on the minimization of a cost functional. The planner thus results in a decision support tool for operators that suggests the best course of action during changes in operating points or process reconfiguration due to the occurrence of faults.

div.head: E.2 Planning framework
div.p: To design a planning framework that can mimic an operators role in process supervision, the planning environment has to be set-up, such that the operators perception of the system and his/her means of influence are represented. It is assumed that the system under investigation is a continuous process with input-dependent stationary operating points and that the operator has complete knowledge of the means of influencing the process, e.g. set-point changes or manual adjustment of manipulated variables, and that he/she has at least qualitative knowledge about the effects of said means.

The planning framework should be capable of defining a plan based on qualitative effects, while remaining open to extensions that integrate quantitative knowledge, such as transition times and magnitudes. To remain open to such extensions, the planning environment has to be quantitative rather than qualitative. The following sections define the main constituents of the planning framework.

div.head: E.2.1 State space
div.p: The state of a process, as an operator can perceive it, is defined by the available process variables, meaning measurements and manipulated variables. Each process variable is bounded with known bounds. The state x is defined as the vector containing a specific value for each process variable
div.formula: x i ∈ [x i,min , x i,max ]. The state space X ⊆ X B = {[x 1 , ..., x n ]|x i ∈ [x i,min , x i,
div.p: max ]} is the set of all possible states the system can assume. If unity-based normalization is applied to the process variables, the state space can be defined as X ⊆ X B = [0, 1] n , where n is the number of process variables. The state space X is the subset of of all valid process configurations within the n-dimensional cubic space X B that is formed by the bounds of the process variables or, if only steady state operation is considered, the subset of all valid steady state configurations of the process. It is not possible to determine the exact shape of the subset without quantitative knowledge of the system dynamics. For steady state analysis it is possible to infer that the state space forms a p-dimensional manifold within X B , where p is equal to the degrees of freedom of the process. This follows directly from the observation that for each unique configuration of independent manipulated variables, and thus degrees of freedom, the process will assume a unique stationary operating point, if the manipulated variables themselves are included in the definition of the state.

div.head: E.2.2 Action space
div.p: The action space U contains all actions available to the operator in a given situation. Some actions might only be available for specific process configurations, resulting in a state-dependent action space. Every action is defined as a tuple (u ′ i , δ ui ) of action identifier and action magnitude. A typical example of an operator action, taking manual control of a valve position, could e.g. be described by the tuple ('open valve', 10%). The operator has the option of either increasing or decreasing any manipulated variable, including control set-points, in the process. While decreasing a manipulated variable can be represented by a negative δ u , it was decided to create separate actions for increasing and decreasing actions, thus only allowing δ u > 0. The magnitude of each action is bounded by the difference between the current state of the manipulated variable and its maximum or the current state and its minimum for increasing and decreasing actions, respectively.

div.head: E.2.3 Representing qualitative effects
div.p: In the context of this paper, a qualitative effect is defined as an effect with a known direction of change but unknown magnitude, which can be described by non-deterministic state transitions LaValle, 2006. Considering future extensions of the planner that feature quantitative information, describing state transitions nondeterministically seems impractical. Instead, a deterministic state transition model that uses process feedback to account for uncertainty about the effect-magnitude is used in this contribution.

div.head: E.2.4 State-transition function
div.p: The qualitative effects of all actions are summarized in an effect matrix G(x) = [(g T (x, u 1 ), ..., g T (x, u m )] T , an m×n matrix for action and state spaces of m and n dimensions, respectively. The state transition, without explicitly modeling uncertainty, is written as x ′ = f (x, u) = x + δ u g T (x, u). The uncertainty about the state transition can be modeled explicitly as a nature action θ, which is a natural extension of the presented planning framework, but not considered further in this contribution.

div.head: E.2.5 Effect matrix
div.p: As mentioned in Section E.2.4, the effect matrix summarizes the qualitative effect of the actions in the action space on all variables in the state vector. Considering only qualitative effects, actions must either increase or decrease variables or leave them unaffected, so that the configuration s of any process variable following an action must be within the set {1, 0, -1}, where 1, 0 and -1 encode "increased", "not affected" and "decreased", respectively. Given a causal model of a system in form of a signed directed graph G = (V, E), for which the set of vertices V includes the measured and manipulated process variables and the set of signed edges E describes their causal relations, the propagation of effects originating in single process variables through the system can be estimated using graph propagation, as shown by Yang et al., 2013. Simple graph propagation, however, does not consider the influence of control systems correctly and thus leads to spurious results. Different approaches to describe control systems in causal models have been presented in e.g. Suresh et al., 2019 andMaurya et al., 2006, but typically involve additional modeling effort. The propagation strategy presented in this paper in Algorithm 2 correctly derives the steady-state development of variables in closed-loop systems given knowledge of the active controlloops. Control loops are indicated in the causal model by marking controlled variables as "controlled" and by labeling the edges from controlled to manipulated variables as "control edges". It is further assumed that the configuration of a node is determined through the shortest path from the root of the propagation, which is enforced by maintaining a set D of already visited "dead nodes" while propagating using a breadth first approach that maintains a list of active nodes A. An example of the derivation of an effect matrix is provided in Section E.4.2.

div.head: E.2.6 Representing time
div.p: The inclusion of qualitative effects in the action space entails that the duration of the actions can typically not be estimated. Thus, it is sufficient to represent the sequence of actions by an increasing stage index k.

div.head: E.2.7 Formalization
div.p: Having introduced the different components of the planner, we can now formalize the planning framework. The state space X is a nonempty, uncountably infinite set representing all possible states the system under investigation could assume. The action space U is a finite, nonempty set of, possibly state dependent, actions. The action space includes a termination action u T , which does not result in a state change and is applied when the current state is within the goal set X G . The state transition function yields a new state, given the current state and action. A set of stages k denotes the relative temporal ordering of the states that are part of the devised plan. An explicit initial state x I ∈ X is defined for each application of the planning problem. Different from the initial state, the goal set X G ⊂ X is defined as a continuous region. The cost L as a function of a state history xF and action history ũK is defined as the sum of the state and action dependent transition costs l(x, u) and the cost associated with the state that is reached after the execution of the plan, which is defined as a potential function ϕ(x) on the state space.

div.head: State space: X
div.formula: ⊆ X B = [x i,min , x i,max ] n 2. Action space: U (x) = [(u 1 , δ u,1 ), ..., (u m , δ u,m ), u T ]

The system is described by the following set of equations

div.p: The simulations are based on the controller and plant parameters specified in Johansson and Nunes, 2000, with additional outputs for the water levels h 3 and h 4 .
A clamping-based anti-windup scheme is added to improve the performance of the integrator of the implemented PI-controllers after extended periods of non-rejectable steady-state error.

The voltages v 1 and v 2 are used by PI regulators to regulate the water levels h 1 and h 2 , while the valve positions γ 1 and γ 2 are manipulated variables available to the human operator to act on the process. When modifying the valve positions, it has to be considered that the system is only minimum phase for γ 1 + γ 2 > 1, and that control performance degrades for other configurations. Measurement noise on the four tank levels is introduced as white Gaussian noise N (0, σ 2 ) with σ = 0.25mm.
div.formula: -γ 2 ) (1 -γ 1 ) γ 2 γ 1 h 4 h 3 h 2 h 1 v 2 v 1 Figure E.1: Quadruple-tank system
div.p: propagation, resulting in the following effect matrix for the system in closed-loop operation

To clarify, the steady-state propagation of an increase of the control set-point for the tank level h 1 , summarized in the first row of (E.7), is described. The graph propagation is initialized by setting the configuration of the manipulated variable belonging to the control-loop of tank 1 to s(v 1 ) = 1 and marking node v 1 as a dead node. The graph propagation along the edges (v 1 , h 1 ) and (v 1 , h 4 ) yields s(h 1 ) = 1 and s(h 4 ) = 1. In the subsequent iteration, the control edge (h 1 , v 1 ) is not propagated because v 1 was previously marked as a dead node, but the propagation along (h 4 , h 2 ) results in s(h 2 ) = 1. Because h 2 is a controlled variable, the corresponding subroutine in Algorithm 2 is activated, resulting in the assignment s(v 2 ) = -1 through the control edge (h 2 , v 2 ) and subsequent reassignment of s(h 2 ) = 0, indicating that the configuration of h 2 will not change once dynamics have settled, because the controller eventually rejects the disturbance. The final assignment yields s(h 3 ) = -1 along the edge (v 2 , h 3 ), since s(v 2 ) = -1 was set in the previous iteration. The iteration terminates following the assignment of h 3 , because there are no edges leading to nodes that are not marked as dead from h 3 , leading to the default assignments s(γ 1 ) = 0, s(γ 2 ) = 0 for the remaining two variables.

div.head: E.4.3 Cost function
div.p: It is assumed that state transitions entail no cost, so that the cost of an action is defined as the cost of the resulting state, ϕ(x ′ ). The potential function serving as a heuristic for the cost of a state, ϕ(x), is defined as the Euclidean distance between the state and an ideal goal state x G ∈ X G , i.e. ϕ(x) = ||xx G || 2 . The cost function is not applied to the full state vector, but to a subset of goal variables of the state vector for which the goal state is known prior to the execution of the plan. For the quadruple-tank system, a typical subset of goal variables is {h 1 , h 2 , h 3 , h 4 }. The termination criterion is met if the state lies within the defined goal set.

div.head: E.4.4 Greedy algorithm
div.p: The implemented planner searches using a greedy best-first approach, as presented by LaValle, 2006. At each planning step, m potential new states are evaluated, where m is the number of applicable actions in the current measured state x. The locally optimal action u best = arg min u (l(x, u) + ϕ(g(x, u))) is chosen for execution until the next iteration of the planning algorithm.

div.head: E.4.5 Scenarios
div.p: Scenario 1, displayed in Fig. E.4 describes the planning for a change in operating point during nominal operation that cannot be handled by changing only the control inputs v 1 and v 2 for h 1 and h 2 , but requires process modifications outside the nominal control scheme. Scenario 2 describes the same change in operating point as Scenario 1, and additionally imposes constraints on the valid region of the state space, requiring that the water level h 2 < 0.11m, until the level in tank 1 satisfies h 1 > 0.13m. This constraint is imposed by defining a rectangular obstacle region X obstacle = [0m, 0.13m] × [0.11m, 0.2m] in the h 1 , h 2 subspace of the state space, which has to be avoided by the planner. This scenario is meant to demonstrate how operational constraints can be represented in the planning framework. Fig . E.3 shows the different developments of the water levels in tanks 1 and 2 that result from the additional constraints. Scenario 3 describes a reconfiguration of the process in case of a diagnosed partial failure of pump 1. The pump capacity is reduced by 75% at t = 200s, leading to a situation in which the desired set-points of the water levels in the bottom tanks cannot be reached and in which h 1 is no longer controlled, since pump 1 constantly operates at maximum efficiency. This new configuration is accounted for by removal of the control edge (h 1 , v 1 ) in the causal graph and calculation of a new effect matrix using Algorithm 2, which yields

The goal of the planning algorithm is to reconfigure the system such that the water levels in the bottom tanks are returned to the states they were at before the pump failure. Fig. E.5 shows the reconfiguration of the system after the activation of the planner at t = 1000 to the desired goal state by compensating for the lack of pump 1 with an increase of the flow through pump 2 and an adjustment of the three-way valves γ 1 and γ 2 . The initial and ideal goal states for the scenarios are summarized in Table E

div.head: E.4.6 Results
div.p: The planner finds a feasible path from the initial to the goal configuration for all presented scenarios. Scenario 2 illustrates that operational constraints can be considered as part of the planning scheme as long as they can be formulated as obstacles in the state space. Scenario 3 shows that the planning framework is capable of re-configuring the system in a fault scenario, if it is provided with the information about the source of the fault. In practice, this requires a fault diagnosis scheme which is capable of fault isolation.

div.head: E.4.7 Discussion
div.p: The planner activates in three situations: (i) the operator changes the desired process operating-point, i.e. a new goal set X G is defined; (ii) a fault is diagnosed which determines the need of combined manual and automated action to steer the process into the goal set; (iii) a disturbance enters the control loop and the automatic control action does not suffice to keep the process in the goal region. At the stage k the planner assesses if the state is in the goal region and suggests the locally optimal action u k ∈ U to the human operator. The operator should then execute the suggested action and leverage his/her expert knowledge to quantify its magnitude. At the next iteration, based on the received feedback from the process, the planner re-assesses the situation and suggests a new locally optimal action u k+1 ∈ U , potentially confirming the previous one, i.e. u k+1 = u k , to the operator. The frequency upon which the planner is run is a tuning parameter that depends on the dominant time constants of the continuous process to be regulated.

While the results are promising, using a greedy planner does not guarantee that a feasible path is found since there is the risk of "getting stuck" in a local minimum of the potential function ϕ(x). This problem could be addressed by using tabu search or by combining greedy search with random walks. Further, the planner may output a less reliable plan for systems with fast transient dynamics since the underlying state transition model is derived for steady-state configurations.

div.head: E.5 Conclusions
div.p: A framework for discrete planning of human operations in automated continuous processes is presented. The framework uses causal models in the form of signed directed graphs to represent the effect of manual and automatic control actions onto the process variables at steady state. This qualitative knowledge is encoded in an effect matrix that underpins the state transition function utilized to explore the state space when the process changes its point of operation or needs to reconfigure due to faults. The planning framework can accommodate variable levels of quantitative knowledge about the continuous process and can generate plans of variable length. The planner's performance using models that assume very limited system knowledge was successfully demonstrated on the quadruple-tank system, utilizing a greedy search algorithm with a single-stage planning horizon (one operator action) to compensate for modeling uncertainty. The proposed causal model-based planner works as a decision support tool for control room operators by providing a qualitative proposal about the best course of action to regain desired steady state operation after intentional or unexpected changes of the process operating point.

div.head: F.1 Introduction
div.p: Large industrial plants are operated by human operators who interact with automatic control systems. Alarm systems and continuous process measurements provide the means for human operators to assess the plant state and reason about possible improvements regarding the current configuration. It has been shown that the amount of available information can overwhelm operators, especially in emergency situations that produce many alarms and deviating trends in a short amount of time. Scenarios where operators are overwhelmed often result in insufficient situational awareness and subsequently sub-optimal decision making. Early fault-detection approaches can be used to increase the available time to assess a given situation. Apart from early faultdetection, online reasoning systems that provide contextual information about the plant-state can actively support the operators decision-making process. Functional C. Reinartz et al. (2021b) modeling methods, such as Multilevel Flow modeling (MFM) Lind (2011a), have been shown to be capable of reasoning about abnormal situations in large processes and to produce humanly interpretable results. MFM models have been used for assisted root-cause analysis given a set of alarm signals and deviating trends, as well as for automated generation of counteraction procedures for abnormal plant scenarios Song and Gofuku (2018) and Song et al. (2020).

A review of existing research utilizing MFM for counteraction planning shows that the existing modeling methodology is typically extended to enable it's utilization for planning purposes Gofuku and Kondo (2011), Inoue andGofuku (2016), andSong et al. (2020). In order to further facilitate MFM based planning, it is imperative to incorporate functionalities that have been shown to be useful for MFM based planning into the modeling language. This contribution presents this formal inclusion, introducing the explicit representation of operator control actions in MFM. A MFM model of a pressurized water reactor is used to demonstrate the inclusion of the new modeling elements and to illustrate their potential use for automated suggestion and evaluation of potential countermeasures, given an abnormal plant state.

div.head: F.2 Multilevel flow modeling
div.p: Multilevel Flow Modeling (MFM) is a functional modeling language capable of capturing causal-dependencies of complex-processes. The description of process subsystems and their design intentions as causally dependent mass, energy and control flow structures makes MFM especially suitable for the description of continuous systems, such as production plants in the chemical and energy industries. Based on a set of generic flow functions and relations Zhang (2015), MFM enables automated reasoning Nielsen et al. (2020) and planning for severe accident management Song et al. (2020). Both reasoning about root-causes of observed process deviations and alarms as well as consequence reasoning about the effects of such deviations follow the same reasoning pattern. Given an inference-root, a set of reasoning rules is triggered that iteratively propagates the state of the inference-root through the MFM model until all functions reachable from the root have been assigned an inferred state. To avoid redundant propagation, Kirchhübel (2020b) proposes a method that detects previously reached reasoning states and merges the corresponding reasoning paths. A comprehensive description of the MFM modeling approach, design intentions and the reasoning system is provided by Lind (2011a) and Zhang (2015).

div.head: F.2.1 Operator control actions in MFM
div.p: In the context of MFM for industrial plants, operator control actions refer to shortterm actions that a control room operator may take to improve the plant condition. It is implied that a counteraction is required because the plant is operating outside its nominal operating point and the implemented control system is unable to cope with the existing disturbance or fault without human intervention. As described in Section F.2, MFM reasoning is generally initiated through the application of the MFM inference rules with a specific starting point, meaning a specific function in the MFM model with a valid MFM state. For counteractions analysis, those MFM functions that represent process elements directly accessible by the operators are selected as starting points. Recognizing the need to identify these functions in an MFM model, Song and Gofuku (2018) associate additional information V (x) = (P (x), f u (x), f d (x), S(x), A(x), Com(x), O(x), Con(x)) with each MFM function. The MFM function type P (x), the up-and downstream relations f u , f d , and the state S(x) are already explicitly represented in the MFM model. Of the remaining elements, the set of possible operations on the function O(x) and the condition for the execution of these operations Con(O(x)) are directly considered in this contribution.

div.head: F.2.2 Formal inclusion of counteraction planning in MFM
div.p: The introduced changes to the MFM modeling language achieve two goals. Information about inference-roots that represent operator control actions is directly encoded in the MFM model and information about the conditions under which an operator can execute the control actions are defined.

Explicitly represented targets and hazards in the MFM model correspond to operational boundaries that govern the operators' interaction with the process as they define production, safety or economic constraints imposed on the process. These boundaries are represented by targets, corresponding to a band of operation, and hazards which refer to one-sided boundaries, i.e. the process needs to be maintained above (hazard: low/less) or below a boundary (hazard: high/more) Wu et al. (2020b). New graphical elements for low (b) and high (c) hazard are introduced. To mitigate an escalating situation in the process, operators can choose to -temporarily -violate or move these boundaries.

The description of operator control actions that affect automatic control loops follows a singular pattern, shown in Fig. F.2. The control-structure pattern remains unchanged from its initial definition by Lind Lind (2011b). The controlled variable is associated with the objective of control and the manipulated variable is indicated by an ACTUATE relation. It is assumed that a human operator has generic means of influencing the behaviour of a controller; adjustment of the control set-point or activation of manual control followed by a direct manipulation of the actuated variable.

Based on these two patterns, candidates for intervention are either manipulated variables indicated by an ACTUATE relation, or those functions that support a process objective which is not directly controlled by automatic control. The functions associated with manipulated variables or targets (band of operation) provide opportunity to increase or decrease the corresponding function state, while those associated with hazards (one-sided boundaries) can only be adjusted in the direction that op-poses the specified hazard. A safety relief valve, for instance, can be opened to release over-pressure, but it can't be used for pressure increase.

div.head: F.3 Case-study
div.p: The case-study presents the addition of the presented counteraction logic into an existing MFM model of a pressurized water reactor (PWR), which has been used for online diagnosis of the primary side of the PWR.

div.head: F.3.1 Process and emergency scenario
div.p: The utilized process is modeled after an anonymized 3-loop Westinghouse pressurized water reactor and implemented as a full-scale simulator in the Hammlab facility Hammlab (2021) at the Institute for Energy Technology in Norway. The main subsystems of the primary side of the PWR, namely the pressurizer, coolant storage and circulation, the over-pressure protection system and reactivity control systems are modeled. The process measurements available for these subsystems are listed in Table F.1. The investigated scenario shows the reaction of the measured variables to a leak in the pressurizer relief valve. Considering that the nominal process operation is very stable, any visible deviations picked up by the sensors can be interpreted as a reaction to an abnormal situation. The qualitative reactions of all process variables are summarized in Table F.1 and corresponding trends of a selection of these variables is shown in Fig. F.4. MFM propagation rules are applied to these deviations to identify the most likely root cause, which is correctly identified as the failure of the pressurizer relief valve (failed open). Immediate consequences are pressure, level, and temperature reduction in the pressurizer due to increased outflow. The decrease of the pressurizer level triggers an automatic increase of the charging flow which in turn results in a reduction of the charging systems volume control tank. Further secondary effects include the reduction of the letdown flow (pressure driven) and the pressurizer waterspace temperature. Downstream consequences of the valve failure are increased flow into the pressurizer relief tank (PRT), leading to an increase of the pressurizer relief valve temperature due to the high throughput of hot steam. Additional consequences are the increase of the PRT level and pressure.

The correct operator control action in this scenario, following the correct rootcause identification, is to close the PRT block valve (RC115 in the MFM model) and to subsequently use a redundant system for pressure relief.

div.head: F.3.2 Modeled operator control actions
div.p: The MFM model of the PWR is shown in Fig. F.3. Model components that correspond to the inclusion of the newly introduced operator control actions in MFM are highlighted in orange. Table F.2 summarizes the encoded operator actions and the conditions that must be met for execution of such actions. Five of the listed actions represent the operators' potential influence on automatic control systems in the pro- cess. The closing of the PRT block valve (RC115 -decrease) as well as changing the production output are included as a manual operator action, as they are not part of the automatic control system.

div.head: F.3.3 Reasoning example
div.p: Given a description of the plant state in an emergency situation, such as the summary of the process variables in operator actions, MFM consequence reasoning Zhang et al. (2013) produces consequence trees that summarize the expected influence of that action on the process. The potential impact of each each possible operator action on the process can be evaluated based on its consequence tree. The consequence tree for the inference root RC115 -low, which corresponds to closing the PRT block valve, is shown in Fig. F.5. The result indicates that this action will indeed oppose all observed process deviations. This suggestion is the most recommendable, since closing the block valve eliminates the original root cause; the leak through the pressurizer relief valve. By capturing all intervention points and thus possible operator actions, the MFM model can be used to assess which actions are meaningful in a given situation.

div.head: F.4 Conclusion
div.p: Two means of representing operator intervention points in Multilevel Flow models are presented. One representation focuses on an operators ability to change the process through the modification of existing automatic control systems, while the other focuses on actions that represent manual operator intervention in the process, such as the activation of safety valves. MFM syntax for both cases is introduced and demonstrated using a case study featuring a pressurized water reactor. These additions are vital to the extension of the modeling language, because they extend the languages scope to include active operator support. Applying the established MFM inference to the identified intervention points, the assessment of an actions efficacy is demonstrated in this paper. The ongoing research focuses on improving the consequence tree generation as well as the development of well-defined ranking of suggested interventions. A classification of process objectives by their association with plant safety, production quality and efficiency is currently being investigated to support sound decisions in the context of the plant operation.

div.head: G.1 Introduction
div.p: Drinking water production in Denmark is based on fresh ground water which is pumped up from underground reservoirs. To improve the operation of drinking water treatment plants it is important to facilitate performance monitoring. Commonly G Automated operator support for small-scale production plants -A water treatment case-study submitted to 26th IEEE International Conference on Emerging Technologies and Factory Automation used attempts utilize advanced instrumentation schemes and recent developments in analysis and machine learning to increase awareness of anomalies in unit operations.

Reasoning about the plant-wide impact and likely root-causes of such anomalies is left to human operators, though. The current status quo presents two difficulties regarding the counteraction of process anomalies in smaller production or treatment plants, irrespective of the specific domain of application. Firstly, small plants are often not as heavily instrumented as large modern industrial plants, making machine learning approaches that require large amounts of data less feasible. Further, such plants are often operated by a single part-time operator instead of a team of full-time operators, meaning that the correct identification of potential anomalies depends even stronger on that particular operators expertise and process understanding. Proper computerized documentation of the plant topology and previous incidents can provide guidance to operators, but neither of these provide automatic reasoning and decision support for general anomalies. Functional modeling methods like Multilevel Flow Modeling (MFM) Lind, 2011a are capable of encoding operational knowledge, enabling the automated analysis of atypical process conditions. Most applications of MFM focus on the analysis of complex large-scale systems Song and Gofuku, 2018, which is further facilitated by recent advances regarding the automatic generation of MFM models from existing process documentation Song et al., 2020. In contrast to that, this contribution investigates the merits of MFM for smaller processes with a lower degree of instrumentation, where plant documentation and human process understanding contribute most to process analysis. It is analyzed to which degree such operational knowledge can be encoded in a MFM model in order to enable automatic operator support using automated model-based reasoning. The required modeling concepts and functionality of the MFM reasoning engine are described in Section G.2. The case-study focuses on a recent (2015)(2016)(2017)(2018)(2019)(2020)(2021) anomaly in a waterworks near Copenhagen, Denmark, featuring an in-depth analysis of the anomaly as well as the measures that were undertaken to return the water treatment plant to nominal operation. A detailed description of the subject of the case-study is provided in Section G.3. The results of the analysis based on the current model and reasoning system are presented in Section G.4. Based on the results, Section G.5 features a discussion about the feasibility and potential extensions of the presented method.

div.head: G.2 Functional modeling approach
div.p: Process systems engineering concerns the development of systematic techniques for process modeling, design and control Sargent, 1983. Many methods and software tools that address process systems engineering have already been developed and found wide industrial application Pistikopoulos et al., 2021. An essential aspect of process systems engineering is model building, often based upon first engineering principles complemented with data driven modeling. The insight behind development of first principles engineering models have been shown to enable development of qualitative functional models, such as MFM models Jørgensen et al., 2019 that describe the qualitative behavior and design intentions of the system and its subsystems. Functional models have proven useful both in the early stages of of process design and for process monitoring, analysis and counteraction planning Myllerup et al., 2019a;Song and Gofuku, 2018.

div.head: G.2.1 Multilevel Flow Modeling
div.p: MFM models provide a qualitative representation of domain knowledge and process functionalities of continuous processes. A structured MFM modeling procedure was developed to formalize the acquisition and utilization of domain knowledge, which improves the consistency of the model building process Wu et al., 2020b. System knowledge is obtained from process experts and plant documentation, such as piping and instrumentation diagrams (P&ID). The knowledge acquisition phase leads to a comprehensive summary of the system, visualized by a function-stream diagram and a objective-function tree. The function-stream diagram provides and abstract representation of material, energy, and control information flows in the process and the objective-function tree captures the relation between high-level system objectives and their low-level realization. Both diagrams are subsequently used to identify appropriate hierarchies and subsystems for the MFM model. The main elements of the knowledge acquisition phase are represented in

div.head: G.3 Case-study
div.p: The examined waterworks uses a well-established treatment process. The water is stripped with air to remove dissolved gases and oxygenated to enable iron and manganese carbonates to precipitate. The precipitates are removed in a sand filter and further biological filtering is applied to remove ammonia. The pumping, serial filtration and water storage setup is displayed in the process flow diagram in Fig. G.2. The on-line instrumentation in the plant focuses on flow-rates, pressures and levels whereas the chemical measurements are sampled offline at regular prescribed intervals.

The raw water at this local drinking water treatment plant contains methane which is removed by stripping the water with air, which in turn saturates the water with oxygen. In an initial filtration step, iron and manganese oxides are removed as solid deposits. Further filtration in the first and second filters utilizes a biofilm, consisting of a mixture of microbes, to remove various unwanted impurities such as ammonia. To establish the biofilm it is essential to oxygenate the water and ensure supply of vital trace metals, especially copper, which are necessary for the enzymes which catalyse the two-stage ammonia oxidation process Ensign et al., 1993. Specifically, ammonia removal is achieved through a two-stage oxidation process to nitrate, with nitrite as an intermediate product. Proper removal of ammonia is vital, because ammonium residues in the finished water can lead to biological after-growth in non-disinfected distribution systems, which can involve oxygen depletion, taste and odor problems, material corrosion, and accumulation of toxic intermediate nitrite.

div.head: G.3.1 Ammonia increase after 2015
div.p: In the water treatment plant under study there was an occurrence of increased ammonia concentration in the drinking water, as shown by the sample measurements displayed in Fig. G.3. A significant change in the ammonia and nitrite concentration in late 2015 is observable. In order to reduce the amount of ammonia in the water, modified filter flushing schedules were attempted several times initially with some limited success, as partial removal of ammonia was achieved, while nitrite concentrations remained above the nominal level. Recurrence of the issue in the time-span 2016-2019 resulted in further investigations, including a focused investigation of the microbial biofilm. The investigation yielded that a replacement of an old iron water well pipe with a new stainless steel pipe led to a reduction of trace metals in the raw water, resulting in a reduction of trace ions. It was found that the copper deficiency in particular limited the nitrification, as has also been observed in previous studies Wagner et al., 2016. The literature reveals similar behavior in several other waterworks in Denmark as published by Wagner et al., 2018. In September 2020 a copper addition unit was inserted into the second filter, which reduced the ammonia at that time from 0.42 mg/l to about half that value. Consequently, the copper addition unit was moved to the first filter in November 2020. Two weeks later the measurements in the water treatment plant outlet fulfilled the requirements.

div.head: G.4 Analysis
div.p: The MFM modeling procedure outlined in Section G.2 is applied to build a model of the waterworks, including the pumping and filtration units. Potential causes of undesired process behaviour, listed in Table G.1, were identified during modeling. MFM reasoning is applied to establish which of these root-causes is causally connected to the sets of observed symptoms belonging to the presented scenarios.

div.head: G.4.1 Ammonia increase
div.p: Given the evidences that both ammonia and nitrite concentrations are high, the automated reasoning produces the results presented in Fig. G.4. The reasoning engine identifies that, of the candidates listed in Table G.1, low copper concentrations in either the first or second filter or a general lack of enzymes due to insufficient establishment of the biofilm can explain both high ammonia and high nitrite concentrations, while reduced concentrations of phosphorus or dissolved oxygen and potential filter clogging only support one of these symptoms. This information is sufficient for operators to identify the correct countermeasure, namely the manual copper injection into the system. Additionally, the information that human operators have the means to inject copper into the system can be included in the MFM model, so that the countermeasure is identified automatically as part of the analysis. The reasoning results further indicate that the current MFM model does not distinguish between a copper injection in the first and second filters. Considering that the injection into the first filter showed significantly better reduction of ammonia and nitrite, this is identified as an issue that will be addressed in the next model improvement iteration.

div.head: G.4.2 Filter clogging
div.p: A second scenario investigates the common occurrence of filter clogging in the plant.

In the examined case-study, observed indicators are a high bottom pressure and a high water level in the mechanical filter. The automatic reasoning system correctly identifies filter clogging as the most likely root-cause. Filter clogging is a well-known issue that occurs frequently and is usually correctly identified by plant operators.

Identifying it automatically still adds value to the plant operation though, because it streamlines the reasoning and consequently reduces the time until the correct countermeasures, such as more frequent filter backwash, are initiated.

div.head: G.5 Results and Discussion
div.p: MFM is successfully applied to a local water treatment plant in the greater Copenhagen area and automated reasoning based on the developed model for two casestudies are in accord with the plant operators evaluations.

The case-study revealed several significant, if not unexpected, differences between the application of MFM to small, sparsely instrumented processes from it's application to large-scale industrial process plants. The first difference concerns the modeling procedure. The scope of the knowledge acquisition procedure shown in Fig. G.1 is reduced, because process descriptions and procedures are typically not developed as thoroughly for smaller plants. Specifically, standard operating procedures and HAZOP documentation are often either incomplete or missing, meaning that they can't be used in the model building and validation process, thus increasing the relevance of precise identification of MFM model structures from P&IDs and process flow diagrams. The second difference concerns the automatic reasoning system. Considering that automatic reasoning is triggered by alarms and deviating trends, it's direct dependency on the degree of on-line instrumentation is apparent. For heavily instrumented processes, MFM root-cause analysis can produce accurate results, because it can utilize many evidences from different sensors. For less instrumented processes such as the case-study, the reasoning yields a list of potential root-cause candidates with similar ranking values that will require further analysis by the operators. Considering that insufficient instrumentation concerns human operators similarly to it's effect on the automated reasoning accuracy, an interesting application of MFM for smaller plants is the identification of ideal locations for new sensors, using the expected increase in diagnostic accuracy as the performance metric. Such a use of MFM during the design and process improvement phase can help operators to optimize available resources. It is planned that the presented case-study is extended to add the water distribution network connected to the water treatment plant to the existing MFM model in order to enable the diagnosis of the entire water distribution system. The aim of the extended study is to use MFM as described above to identify additional instrumentation that is necessary to isolate and identify the commonly occurring plant failure conditions with high accuracy and to evaluate the benefit of MFM based process monitoring to the operators in the field.

note.p: State of the art3.5 SummaryThe presented state of the art distinguishes between alarm management concerned with the elimination of nuisance alarms and redundant alarm configuration and decision support systems concerned with the contextualization of sequences of true alarms that can occur in abnormal operating scenarios. Key references for the management of nuisance and redundant alarms are provided, but the focus is on relevant methods that aim to contextualize plant information to enable root-cause analysis and action planning. Within the sub-domain of decision support systems, causal and functional process analysis are reviewed most thoroughly, because these topics are most relevant for the presented PhD project.

The relation to automatic control loop uses the MFM model as a reference. Process variables that are subject to automatic control which is not included in the MFM model will be treated as if they were controlled manually, since the specifics of the automatic control implementations are not modeled. This reflects the logic that these variables can be controlled by an operator, but that the means of such control are outside the current modeling scope.
A multigraph is a graph in which a pair of nodes can be connected by more than one edge with the same orientation.
The introduced sign function is not the signum function.
The direction of causality is the direction from cause to effect in a causal dependency. In a signed directed graph, the base and tip of an edge correspond to cause and effect, respectively.
A node v j is reachable from another node v i , if there exists a path in the graph that starts at v i and ends at v j .
Causal model-based analysis (a) Reference model R1 (b) Reference model R2

Assumptions that are neither inferences nor evidences are usually directly related to the investigation of hypothetical scenarios, such as evaluation of different root-cause candidates for diagnosis. In such cases, propagation is initiated by introducing an initial assumption to the model in order to trigger causal reasoning.

The information about the human operators typical decision process that is referred to was obtained through interviews with experienced control room operators that were conducted during the PhD study.

div.head: Declaration of competing interest
div.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper. Two open research areas are the detection and identification of process faults and the automated generation of plans for process re-configuration. Such research requires access to sufficient amounts of healthy and faulty process data and, for the study of re-configurations, data that describes the behaviour of the process under varying operating conditions. Complex, high fidelity simulators can greatly aid such research, because they provide the option to simulate faults and test experimental process configurations with varying tuning parameters in a safe environment. Due to the benefits mentioned above, sophisticated process simulators have gained popularity, both in industry as well as in multiple research domains. For high-fidelity simulations of wind-turbines in both the testing and design phase, the National Renewable Energy Laboratory present (OpenFAST 2021). For the simulation of complex finite element method (FEM) computations in the fields of electromagnetics and fluid dynamics, (Vencels et al., 2019) present a coupling of the software packages Elmer and OpenFOAM. Such simulators profit from being easily accessible and extendable, ideally in a programming language that is adopted by researchers in the primary application domain of the software. Recently, Python based frameworks have gained popularity, due to both the available ecosystem and large open-source communities. The high degree of adoption of Python as a primary analysis tool, especially for machine learning centered projects, provides a strong incentive to adapt existing research software and simulators to be easily accessible through a Python framework. Zhu et al., 2018 present a Python library that interacts with the OpenSees simulation framework, identifying the need of users to access OpenSees through alternative languages to expand upon existing use cases. A Python interface for the Dutch Atmospheric Large Eddy Simulation (DALES) suite, originally written in Fortran, is presented by Oord et al., 2020 in order to facilitate access to complex features of the original suite. div.head: PAPER C
div.p: Improving situational awareness through explainable AI -Automated root-cause ranking based on causal process models

div.head: C.4 Analysis
div.p: The presented analysis comprises root-cause analysis for the described fault-scenarios based on an evaluation of the MFM model. Analysis based on functional models leverages information about process causalities similar to a human operators natural reasoning process, which makes it interesting as a tool for operator support. The general assumption is made that an observed abnormal event can be traced back to a singular root-cause and that the observed symptoms (deviations from nominal behaviour) are direct or indirect consequences of the actual failure. A root-cause typically corresponds directly to a component malfunction, such as a valve leakage, or to a vital process abnormality, such as reduced reactivity. For the conducted case study, potential root-cause candidates summarized in Table G.1 were identified by process operators. The reasoning at the core of the analysis can be separated into three distinct steps; evidence generation, state propagation and ranking. The focus of this contribution rests on algorithms for the state propagation and ranking, with only a brief introduction to the evidence generation.

div.head: C.4.1 Evidence generation
div.p: The introduced functional models describe the qualitative causal dependencies between process variables. The qualitative nature of the models means that the described propagation can also only handle the qualitative states introduced in Section

div.head: Algorithm 2 propagate_configuration
div.p: The quadruple-tank system is a multivariate laboratory process presented by Johansson and Nunes, 2000. The process consists of four water tanks, which are setup as shown in Fig. E.1, where the water level h i for all tanks is defined on the interval

div.head: E.4 Case-study
div.p: The presented planning framework combined with a greedy planner, which operates using a strict best-first approach LaValle, 2006, is applied to the quadruple-tank system. The modeling uncertainty is expressed implicitly by using immediate statefeedback after a one-stage planning process. To emulate a human operator in the loop, a reference signal generator is used to translate the actions recommended by the greedy planner into set-points following a ramp profile for the control-references and valve positions. The slopes for the reference signals are set as 2.5e -4 ms -1 and 2e -4 s -1 for the water levels and valve positions, respectively to consider the dynamics of the controlled system.

div.head: E.4.1 State and action space
div.p: The eight process variables

based on the bounds of the water levels, voltages and valve positions. Applying normalization, the state space becomes X norm ⊂ [0, 1] 8 . In case of nominal closed-loop control, an operator can influence the process by changing set-points for h 1 and h 2 and manually interfacing with the process through γ 1 and γ 2 , so that the set of actions becomes

, where the superscripts '+' and '-' denote "increase" and "decrease". The magnitude of all actions in the normalized space is set to δ u = 0.005, so that the state transition function described in Section E.2.4 becomes f (x, u) = x + 0.005g T (x, u).

div.head: E.4.2 Causal graph and effect matrix
div.p: The causal model for the quadruple-tank system, represented by the signed directed graph shown in Fig. E.2, is generated from (E.1)-(E.4) using the procedure shown by Yang et al., 2013 for the extraction of signed directed graphs from differential equations. For the differential equation
the sign of edges of causally connected variables is given by sgn (x j → x i ) = sgn ∂f i /∂x j x 0 1 ,...,x 0 n , (E.6)

where "sgn (x j → x i )" is the sign of the edge from x j to x i . Graphs derived in this manner typically include both cycles and self-cycles if applied to the analysis of continuous processes. Cycles occur when closed-loop control systems or recycle streams are represented, while self-cycles arise if the derivative of a variable directly depends on the variable itself, as e.g. the water levels h 1 -h 4 in (E.1)-(E.4).
